revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=June 2018}} {{Year nav topic5|1707|music}}
The year '''1707 in music''' involved some significant events.
==Events== *[[George Frideric Handel]] meets [[Domenico Scarlatti]] in [[Venice]]. *[[Johann Sebastian Bach]] marries his second cousin, [[Maria Barbara Bach]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=Don |first1=Randel |title=The Harvard Biographical Dictionary of Music |date=1996 |publisher=Harvard University Press |isbn=9780674372993 |page=37 |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=jEGpMqRcQjIC&pg=PA37|language=en}}</ref> *[[Antonio Caldara]] leaves his post in Mantua to become ''maestro di cappella'' to Prince Ruspoli in Rome. *[[William Croft]] becomes "Master of the Children" at the Chapel Royal, in succession to Clarke. *[[Domenico Zipoli]] becomes a pupil of organist Giovani Maria Casini in Florence.
==Published popular music== *''Hymns and Spiritual Songs'' by [[Isaac Watts]] (including "When I Survey the Wondrous Cross")<ref>{{cite web |title=Isaac Watts – British minister |url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Isaac-Watts |website=Encyclopedia Britannica |accessdate=16 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==Classical music== *[[Tomaso Albinoni]] – Op. 5, a collection of concerti *[[Johann Sebastian Bach]] — [[Christ lag in Todes Banden, BWV 4|''Christ lag in Todes Banden'', BWV 4]] ([[Chorale cantata (Bach)|chorale cantata]]) *[[Alessandro Scarlatti]] – ''Cain, overo Il primo omicidio'' (oratorio)
==Opera== *Thomas Clayton – ''Rosamond'', book by [[Joseph Addison]], produced in [[London]] *[[Nicola Fago]] – ''Radamisto'' *[[George Frideric Handel|Handel]] – ''[[Rodrigo (opera)|Rodrigo]]'' *[[Johann Christoph Pepusch]] – ''Thomyris, Queen of Scythia'' *[[Alessandro Scarlatti]] – ''Mitridate Eupatore'' *[[Agostino Steffani]] – ''Arminio''
==Births== *[[April 10]] – [[Michel Corrette]], organist and composer (died [[1795]])<ref>{{cite web |title=Michel Corrette (1707–1795) |url=http://data.bnf.fr/13992396/michel_corrette/ |website=data.bnf.fr |accessdate=16 June 2018 |language=en}}</ref> *[[May 2]] – [[Jean-Baptiste Barrière]], cellist and composer (died [[1747]]) *[[December 18]] – [[Charles Wesley]], hymn-writer (died [[1788]]) *''date unknown'' **[[Matthew Dubourg]], violinist, conductor and composer (died [[1767]]) **[[Zanetta Farussi]], opera singer and composer (died [[1776]]) **[[Edward Harwood (of Darwen)]], composer of hymns, anthems and songs (died [[1787]]) **[[Pietro Domenico Paradisi]], composer and harpsichordist (died [[1791]]) **[[Herman Friedrich Voltmar]], composer (died [[1782]])
==Deaths== *[[February 9]] – [[Giuseppe Aldrovandini]], composer (born [[1665]]) *[[March 30]] – [[Henry Hall (poet)|Henry Hall]], composer of church music (born c. [[1656]]) *[[April 20]] – [[Johann Christoph Denner]], inventor of the clarinet (born [[1655]]) *[[May 9]] – [[Dieterich Buxtehude]], composer (born [[1637]]) *June – [[Gaspard Le Roux]], French harpsichordist (born ''c''.[[1660]]) *[[August 20]] – [[Nicolas Gigault]], organist and composer (born [[1627]]) *[[September 5]] – [[Daniel Speer|Johann Daniel Georg Speer]], composer (born [[1636]]) [http://www.fsz.bme.hu/mtsz/mhk/csarnok/s/speer.htm] *[[December 1]] – [[Jeremiah Clarke]], composer (born c.[[1674]]) *''date unknown'' – [[Julie d'Aubigny]] ("La Maupin"), opera singer (born [[1670]]) *''probable'' – [[Henry Playford]], music publisher (born [[1657]])
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:1707 In Music}} [[Category:1707 in music| ]] [[Category:18th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox Radio station |name = Kool N Deadly (3KND) |image = 3kndlogo.jpg |area = Melbourne, Australia |branding = 3KND |frequency = 1503 kHz AM |airdate = June 2003 |format = Indigenous Issues & Music |language = English / First Languages |power = 5 kW pY |owner = South East Indigenous Media Ass'n Inc |website = {{URL|www.3knd.org.au}} }}
'''3KND''' is a [[community radio]] station which represents the [[Indigenous Australian|Indigenous]] communities within Greater [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[Australia]].<ref name='3KND vision 2007-09-05'>{{cite web | url = http://www.3knd.org.au/vision.htm | title = Vision | accessdate = 2007-09-05 | work = 3KND | publisher = SEIMA Executive Board | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070829221148/http://3knd.org.au/vision.htm | archivedate = 2007-08-29 }}</ref> 3KND broadcasts in Melbourne at 1503 on the AM radio band<ref name='CBOnline 3KND 2007-09-05'>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbonline.org.au/index.cfm?pageId=13,11,6,3223 |title=3KND - Kool and Deadly |accessdate=2007-09-05 |work=CBOnline |publisher=Community Broadcasting Foundation |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070903074850/http://www.cbonline.org.au/index.cfm?pageId=13%2C11%2C6%2C3223 |archivedate=3 September 2007 |deadurl=no }}</ref> and also streams on the internet.<ref name='3KND streaming 2007-09-05'>{{ cite web | url=http://www.3knd.org.au/streaming.htm | title=Live Streaming |accessdate=2007-09-05 |work=3KND | publisher=SEIMA Executive Board |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070829220551/http://3knd.org.au/streaming.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-08-29}}</ref> As at late 2006, 3KND has the beginnings of an mp3 library.<ref name='3KND podcasts 2007-09-05'>{{ cite web |url=http://www.3knd.org.au/podcasts.htm |title=Podcasts |accessdate=2007-09-05 |work=3KND |publisher=SEIMA Executive Board |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829220808/http://3knd.org.au/podcasts.htm |archivedate=29 August 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The South Eastern Indigenous Media Association is the station operator.<ref name='3KND profile 2007-09-05'>{{ cite web |url=http://www.3knd.org.au/profile.htm |title=Profile |accessdate=2007-09-05 |work=3KND |publisher=SEIMA Executive Board |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829220928/http://3knd.org.au/profile.htm |archivedate=29 August 2007 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The station provides training for indigenous broadcasters.<ref name='CBOnline Melb 1st 2007-09-05'>{{ cite web |first= |last=NIRS |coauthors= |title=3KND - Melbourne's First Indigenous Radio Station |date=2004-10-26 |publisher=Community Broadcasting Foundation |url=http://www.cbonline.org.au/index.cfm?pageId=43,127,3,739 |work=CBOnline |pages= |accessdate=2007-09-05 |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830053246/http://www.cbonline.org.au/index.cfm?pageId=43%2C127%2C3%2C739 |archivedate=30 August 2007 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
==History== The 1503 frequency had been previously vacated by [[3AK]] as it moved to occupy 1116 AM<ref name='age.com.au Radio Daze'>{{cite web | first = Brett | last = de Hoedt | coauthors = | title = Radio Daze | date = 2003-06-08 | publisher = Fairfax | url = http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/06/07/1054700443908.html | work = The Age | pages = | accessdate = 2007-09-05 | language = }}</ref> The first test broadcast was in 1998.<ref name='3KND profile 2007-09-05'/>
3KND was one of the later entrants into the temporary community broadcasting period in Melbourne as part of the lead up to the granting of four additional community licences for the City. It was granted the only AM license available for community radio at that time. 3KND was licensed at the same time as [[JOY 94.9]], for the [[LGBT]] community; [[Christian contemporary]]-formatted [[Light FM|Triple 7]] (now LightFM); and the student-run [[SYN Media#Radio|SYN FM]] (now SYN 90.7)<ref name='acma.gov.au NR107/2001'>{{cite media release |title=SYN FM, Triple Seven, SEIMA and Joy to get Melbourne community radio licences |date=2001-12-19 |publisher=Australian Communications and Media Authority |url=http://www.acma.gov.au/WEB/STANDARD/1001/pc=PC_91122 |work=Media release archive |pages= |accessdate=2007-09-05 |language= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071007165722/http://www.acma.gov.au/WEB/STANDARD/1001/pc%3DPC_91122 |archivedate=7 October 2007 |deadurl=no }}</ref> At the time it was founded, 3KND was Melbourne's first Indigenous radio station.<ref name='CBOnline Melb 1st 2007-09-05'/>
Official broadcasting began in June 2003.<ref name='CBOnline 3KND 2007-09-05'/> Internet streaming was introduced in 2006. The launch of 3KND on digital radio in 2010.
==Internet streaming== 3KND's internet streaming is provided <!-- in [[HE-AAC|aacPlus]] format. Suitable client software for the [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]] platform includes: [[Winamp]] Lite, [[foobar2000]], [[MPlayer]] and [[Windows Media Player]] versions 6.4, 7.0, 7.1, 8.0, 9.0, 10.0, 11.0 (with the [http://www.orban.com/plugin/ Orban aacPlus plugin]),<ref name='orban.com aacPlus'>{{ cite web |url=http://www.orban.com/plugin/ |title= Orban/Coding Technologies AAC/aacPlus Player Plugin | accessdate=2007-09-05 | work = Orban | publisher = Orban CRL }}</ref> For the [[Macintosh|Mac]] and other [[Linux|GNU/Linux]] and [[Berkeley Software Distribution|BSD]] platforms suitable client software includes [[MPlayer]] and [[VLC media player]]. The stream is provided at two bit rates: 20 kbit/s and 48 kbit/s.<ref name='3KND streaming 2007-09-05'>{{cite web | url = http://www.3knd.org.au/streaming.htm | title = Live Streaming | accessdate = 2007-09-05 | work = 3KND | publisher = SEIMA Executive Board | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070829220551/http://3knd.org.au/streaming.htm | archivedate = 2007-08-29 }}</ref> --> by [[Internode (ISP)]].<ref name= m3u-from-internode >{{ cite web |url = http://media.on.net/radio/76.m3u |title=3KND streaming m3u |publisher = Internode | accessdate =2010-10-19}}</ref>
==Program categories== <ref name='3KND programs 2007-09-05'>{{cite web |url=http://www.3knd.org.au/programs.htm |title=Programs |accessdate=2007-09-05 |work=3KND |publisher=SEIMA Executive Board |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829221426/http://3knd.org.au/programs.htm |archivedate=29 August 2007 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> * Breakfast * Talkback & Chat * Aboriginal Current Affairs * Sports * Music and Entertainment * Arts News * Health Programs
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.3knd.org.au/ 3KND Official Website]
{{Melbourne AM}} {{Coord|37.7415|S|145.0023|E|type:landmark_region:AU-VIC|display=title}}

[[File:Gerard David - Adoration of the Kings - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Gerard David]], ''[[Adoration of the Kings (David, London)|Adoration of the Kings]]'', [[National Gallery, London]], 1515–1523]] [[File:Gentile da fabriano, adorazione dei magi.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Adoration of the Magi (Gentile da Fabriano)|''Adoration of the Magi'']], [[Gentile da Fabriano]], 1423]] The '''Adoration of the Magi''' or '''Adoration of the Kings''' is the name traditionally given to the subject in the [[Nativity of Jesus in art]] in which the [[Biblical Magi|three Magi]], represented as kings, especially in the West, having found Jesus by following a [[star of Bethlehem|star]], lay before him gifts of [[gold]], [[frankincense]], and [[myrrh]], and worship him. It is related in the Bible by [[Matthew 2:11]]: "On entering the house, they saw the child with Mary his mother; and they knelt down and paid him homage. Then, opening their treasure chests, they offered him gifts of gold, frankincense, and myrrh. And having been warned in a dream not to return to [[Herod the Great|Herod]], they left for their own country by another path". Christian [[iconography]] has considerably expanded the bare account of the [[Biblical Magi]] given in the second chapter of the [[Gospel of Matthew]] ([[Matthew 2:1|2:1]]–[[Matthew 2:11|22]]) and used it to press the point that Jesus was recognized, from his earliest infancy, as king of the earth. The scene was often used to represent the Nativity, one of the most indispensable episodes in cycles of the ''[[Life of the Virgin]]'' as well as the ''[[Life of Christ in art|Life of Christ]]''. In the [[church calendar]], the event is commemorated in [[Western Christianity]] as the Feast of the [[Epiphany (Christian)|Epiphany]] (January 6). The [[Orthodox Church]] commemorates the Adoration of the Magi on the [[Christmas|Feast of the Nativity]] (December 25). The term is [[anglicized]] from the [[Vulgate]] Latin section title for this passage: '''A Magis adoratur'''. ==History of the depiction== [[File:Adoration magi Pio Christiano Inv31459.jpg|thumb|Adoration of the Child Jesus by the three wise men or Magi; [[Sarcophagus]] relief (4th century.), Vatican]] [[File:Jan Gossaert 001.jpg|thumb|[[The Adoration of the Kings (Gossaert)|''Adoration'' by Jan Gossaert]], c. 1510]] [[File:After Hieronymus Bosch - Adoration of the Magi - Petworth House.jpg|thumb|''Adoration of the Magi'' after Hieronymus Bosch]] [[Image:Dieric Bouts 004.jpg|thumb|right| |[[Dirk Bouts]], 15th century]] In the earliest depictions, the Magi are shown wearing Persian dress of trousers and [[Phrygian cap]]s, usually in profile, advancing in step with their gifts held out before them. These images adapt [[Late Antiquity|Late Antique]] poses for barbarians submitting to an Emperor, and presenting golden wreaths, and indeed relate to images of [[tribute]]-bearers from various Mediterranean and ancient Near Eastern cultures going back many centuries. The earliest are from [[catacomb]] paintings and [[sarcophagus]] reliefs of the 4th century. Crowns are first seen in the 10th century, mostly in the West, where their dress had by that time lost any Oriental flavour in most cases.Schiller, Gertrud; Seligman, Janet (1971). ''Iconography of Christian Art, Vol. I: Christ's incarnation, childhood, baptism, temptation, transfiguration, works and miracles,'' (English translation from German), pp. 100–114 and figs. 245–298. London: Lund Humphries. {{OCLC|59999963}} The standard Byzantine depiction of the Nativity included the journey or arrival of the mounted Magi in the background, but not them presenting their gifts, until the post-Byzantine period, when the western depiction was often adapted to an [[icon]] style. Later Byzantine images often show small pill-box like hats, whose significance is disputed. The Magi are usually shown as the same age until about this period, but then the idea of depicting the three ages of man is introduced: a particularly beautiful example is seen on the façade of the [[Orvieto Cathedral|cathedral of Orvieto]]. Occasionally from the 12th century, and very often in Northern Europe from the 15th, the Magi are also made to represent the three known parts of the world: Balthasar is very commonly cast as a young African or Moor, and old Caspar is given Oriental features or, more often, dress. Melchior represents Europe and [[middle age]]. From the 14th century onward, large retinues are often shown, the gifts are contained in spectacular pieces of [[goldsmith]] work, and the Magi's clothes are given increasing attention. By the 15th century, the ''Adoration of the Magi'' is often a bravura piece in which the artist can display their handling of complex, crowded scenes involving horses and camels, but also their rendering of varied textures: the silk, fur, jewels and gold of the Kings set against the wood of the stable, the straw of Jesus's manger and the rough clothing of Joseph and the shepherds. The scene often includes a fair diversity of animals as well: the ox and ass from the [[Nativity scene]] are usually there, but also the horses, camels, dogs, and falcons of the kings and their retinue, and sometimes other animals, such as birds in the rafters of the stable. From the 15th century onwards, the Adoration of the Magi is quite often conflated with the [[Adoration of the Shepherds]] from the account in the [[Gospel of Luke]] (2:8–20), an opportunity to bring in yet more human and animal diversity; in some compositions ([[triptych]]s for example), the two scenes are contrasted or set as pendants to the central scene, usually a [[Nativity scene|Nativity]]. The "adoration" of the Magi at the crib is the usual subject, but their arrival, called the "Procession of the Magi", is often shown in the distant background of a Nativity scene (usual in Byzantine icons), or as a separate subject, for example in the [[Magi Chapel]] frescos by [[Benozzo Gozzoli]] in the [[Palazzo Medici Riccardi]], [[Florence]]. Other subjects include the Journey of the Magi, where they and perhaps their retinue are the only figures, usually shown following the [[Star of Bethlehem]], and there are relatively uncommon scenes of their meeting with [[Herod the Great|Herod]] and the ''[[Dream of the Magi]]''. The usefulness of the subject to the Church and the technical challenges involved in representing it have made the Adoration of the Magi a favorite subject of Christian art: chiefly painting, but also sculpture and even music (as in [[Gian-Carlo Menotti]]'s opera ''[[Amahl and the Night Visitors]]''). The subject matter is also found in [[stained glass]]. The first figural stained glass window made in the United States is the "Adoration of the Magi" window located at Christ Church, Pelham, New York and designed in 1843 by the founder and first rector's son, [[William Jay Bolton]]. ==Treatments by individual artists== [[File:Fra Angelico, Fra Filippo Lippi, The Adoration of the Magi.jpg|thumb|[[Adoration of the Magi (Fra Angelico and Filippo Lippi)|Fra Angelico and Filippo Lippi]], 15th century.]] {{see also|Category:Adoration of the Magi in art}} Many hundreds of artists have treated the subject. A partial list of those with articles follows. * [[Adoration of the Magi (Fra Angelico and Filippo Lippi)|''Adoration of the Magi'']], [[Fra Angelico]] and [[Filippo Lippi]], [[National Gallery of Art]], [[Washington, D.C.]] *[[Adoration of the Magi (Bosch, Madrid)|Hieronymus Bosch, Museo del Prado, Madrid]] * ''[[Adoration of the Magi of 1475 (Botticelli)]]'', [[Sandro Botticelli|Botticelli]]: [[National Gallery of Art]], [[Washington, D.C.]] * [[Triptych of the Virgin's Life (Bouts)|Triptych of the Virgin's Life, Dirk Bouts]] * [[The Adoration of the Kings (Bruegel)|''The Adoration of the Kings'' (Bruegel)]], [[National Gallery, London]] *''[[Star of Bethlehem (painting)|The Star of Bethlehem]]'', [[Edward Burne-Jones]], [[Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery]] *''[[Adoration of the Magi (Andrea della Robbia)]]'', [[Victoria and Albert Museum]] * [[Saint Columba Altarpiece]], [[Rogier van der Weyden]], [[Alte Pinakothek]], Munich *''[[Adoration of the Kings (Gerard David, London)]], National Gallery, London * ''[[Adoration of the Magi (Dürer)]]'', [[Uffizi]], [[Florence]] *''[[The Adoration of the Magi (Geertgen tot Sint Jans)]]'', [[Rijksmuseum]] *[[Adoration of the Magi (Ospedale degli Innocenti)|Domenico Ghirlandaio, Ospedale degli Innocenti, Florence]] * ''[[The Adoration of the Kings (Gossaert)]]'', National Gallery, London *''[[Adoration of the Magi (Mantegna)]]'', Uffizi *''[[Madonna and Child (Masaccio)]]'', [[Gemäldegalerie (Berlin)|Gemäldegalerie]], [[Berlin]] *''[[Adoration of the Magi (Perugino, Perugia)]]'', [[Galleria Nazionale dell'Umbria]], [[Perugia]] *''[[Adoration of the Magi (Rubens, Lyon)]]'', [[Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]] *''[[Adoration of the Magi (Rubens, Cambridge)]]'', [[King's College Chapel, Cambridge]] *''[[Adoration of the Magi (Rubens, Antwerp)]]'', [[Royal Museum of Fine Arts Antwerp]] *''[[Adoration of the Magi (Velázquez)]]'', [[Museo del Prado]], [[Madrid]] *''[[Adoration of the Magi {{good article}} {{Infobox film | name = Akeelah and the Bee | image = Akeelah and the Bee film.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Doug Atchison]] | producer = {{Plainlist| *[[Laurence Fishburne]] *[[Sid Ganis]] *[[Nancy Hult Ganis]] *Danny Llewelyn *Michael Romersa }} | writer = Doug Atchison | starring = {{Plainlist| *Laurence Fishburne *[[Angela Bassett]] *[[Keke Palmer]] <!-- per poster billing --> }} | music = [[Aaron Zigman]] | cinematography = [[M. David Mullen|David Mullen]] | editing = [[Glenn Farr]] | studio = {{Plainlist| *[[Lionsgate Films]] *[[2929 Entertainment]] *[[Starbucks Entertainment]] *Out of the Blue Entertainment *Reactor Films *Cinema Gypsy Productions{{efn|The credits for the film reads "A Lionsgate, 2929 Productions and Starbucks Entertainment presentation of an Out of the Blue and Reactor Films production in association with Cinema Gypsy Productions."<ref name=chang/>{{sfn|Production|2006|p=4}}|name=companies}} }} | distributor = Lionsgate Films | released = {{film date|2006|3|16|[[Cleveland International Film Festival|CIFF]]|2006|4|28|United States}} | runtime = 112 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $6–8 million<ref name=ppgaz>{{cite web|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/movies/2006/04/30/Fishburne-says-Akeelah-touches-on-risky-themes/stories/200604300171 |title=Fishburne says 'Akeelah' touches on risky themes |date=April 30, 2006 |author=Hayes, John |work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] |publisher=[[Block Communications]] |accessdate=June 20, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv1I6oJw?url=http://www.post-gazette.com/ae/movies/2006/04/30/Fishburne-says-Akeelah-touches-on-risky-themes/stories/200604300171 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name=box>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2006/AKELA.php |title=Akeelah and the Bee |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |work=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]] |publisher=Nash Information Services |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv1LpgZ5?url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2006/AKELA.php |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> | gross = $19 million<ref name=box/> }}
'''''Akeelah and the Bee''''' is a 2006 American [[drama (film and television)|drama film]] written and directed by [[Doug Atchison]]. It tells the story of Akeelah Anderson ([[Keke Palmer]]), an 11-year-old girl who participates in the [[Scripps National Spelling Bee]], her mother ([[Angela Bassett]]), her schoolmates, and her coach, Dr. Joshua Larabee ([[Laurence Fishburne]]). The cast also features [[Curtis Armstrong]], J.R. Villarreal, Sean Michael Afable, [[Erica Hubbard]], [[Lee Thompson Young]], Julito McCullum, Sahara Garey, [[Eddie Steeples]], and [[Tzi Ma]].
The film was developed over a period of 10 years by Atchison, who came up with the initial concept after seeing the 1994 [[Scripps National Spelling Bee]] and noting that a majority of the competitors came from well-off socioeconomic backgrounds. After completing the script in 1999, Atchison won one of the [[Nicholl Fellowships in Screenwriting]] in 2000, which attracted producers [[Sid Ganis]] and [[Nancy Hult Ganis]]. After an initial inability to secure funding, the project got a second wind as a result of the success of the 2002 documentary film ''[[Spellbound (2002 film)|Spellbound]]''. [[Lionsgate Films]] undertook the production in 2004 and in the following year it was filmed in [[South Los Angeles]] on a budget of over $6 million.
Atchison remarked that his theme for the film, deemed an inspirational film, was about overcoming obstacles despite difficult challenges along the way. He also said that he wanted to portray African Americans in a manner that was not stereotypical and tried to show how African American children incorporate some stereotypes. The film alludes to the importance of community as well as to problems black communities face. It also deals with esteem and stigma in school while criticizing the public school system. Cast members said that although the film was aimed at children, they considered it had important lessons for the parents as well.
Released in the United States on April 28, 2006, ''Akeelah and the Bee'' was positively received by critics and audiences. Reviewers praised its storyline and cast, lauding Palmer's performance, although a few critics panned the story as familiar and formulaic, and were critical of the portrayal of Asian-American characters. The film grossed $19 million, and received a number of awards and nominations, including the [[Black Reel Awards]] and the [[NAACP Image Award]]s. Film critics highly praised it for avoiding [[Stereotypes of African Americans|African-American stereotypes]] common in Hollywood films, while scholars were less favorable, even saying it reinforces some clichés.
==Plot== Akeelah Anderson, an 11-year-old spelling enthusiast, attends Crenshaw Middle School, a predominantly [[black school]] in [[South Los Angeles|South]] [[Los Angeles]]. She lives with her disgruntled [[widow]]ed mother Tanya, her older sister Kiana, her older brothers Devon and Terrence, and her infant niece. Her principal Mr. Welch suggests that she sign up for the Crenshaw Schoolwide Spelling Bee, which she initially refuses. After being threatened for detention for the remaining of the semester, she gives in, enters the spelling bee, and wins. Soon after, Dr. Joshua Larabee, a visiting English professor and Mr. Welch's friend from college, tests Akeelah and decides that she is good enough to compete in the National Spelling Bee. Nevertheless, Dr. Larabee declines to coach her because she is rude to him. As a result, Akeelah studies on her own to prepare for the district spelling bee. Although Akeelah misspells her word during the final round of the bee, she qualifies for the regional bee when Kiana catches the other finalist cheating. Akeelah also meets and befriends Javier Mendez, a 12-year-old [[Mexican American]] boy and fellow speller. Javier invites her to join the spelling club at his [[Woodland Hills, Los Angeles|Woodland Hills]] middle school.
At Woodland Hills, Akeelah meets Dylan Chiu, a [[Chinese American]] boy who had won second place at the past two national spelling bees. Contemptuous, he asks her to spell "[[xanthosis]]". When she starts with a "z", he tells her she needs a coach. At the conclusion of the spelling club meeting, Javier invites Akeelah to his birthday party. At the party, Akeelah nearly beats Dylan in [[Scrabble]]. The boy is reprimanded by his father for nearly losing to "a little black girl". After the party, Tanya is depressed over Terrence's bad behavior after getting caught by the police for acting out with his thugs, her husband's death after a criminal shot and killed him on his way home from work and concerned about her daughter's grades and frequent [[truancy]]. As she finds out about Akeelah going alone to Woodland Hills, she subsequently forbids Akeelah from participating in the upcoming state bee. To circumvent this prohibition, Akeelah forges her deceased father Samuel's signature on the consent form and secretly studies with Dr. Larabee. During the state bee, Tanya comes inside and interrupts her daughter before she can spell her word. Tanya relents after a side discussion with Dr. Larabee and Mr. Welch, especially giving Akeelah double chores for three months as a punishment for giving it a secret behind her back. Javier protects Akeelah from disqualification by stalling until she can return. Dylan, Javier and Akeelah advance to the Scripps National Spelling Bee.
As Christmas approaches, Akeelah goes out to buy Dr. Larabee a present, but when she meets him, he reveals that he is quitting being her coach because she reminds him of his deceased daughter Denise: being very sick caused her death and that caused his wife Patricia to move into another city. Instead, he gives Akeelah 5,000 flashcards to study. Without her coach, rejected by her best friend Georgia, and feeling the pressure from her neighborhood residents to make them proud, Akeelah loses her motivation. However, Tanya tells her that if she looked around her, she would realize that she has "50,000 coaches". Akeelah recruits her family members, classmates, teachers, friends, and neighbor Derrick T to prepare in earnest. After reuniting with Dr. Larabee, Akeelah goes to [[Washington, D.C.]] with him, along with Tanya, Georgia, Mr. Welch, and Devon, unaware that her coach has paid for four of their tickets. Georgia rekindles her friendship with Akeelah after she invites her. During the competition, Akeelah becomes a crowd favorite. After all the other competitors are eliminated, only Dylan and Akeelah remain. The two finalists are allowed a break, during which Akeelah overhears Dylan's father harshly pressuring him to win. Akeelah attempts to [[match fixing|intentionally lose]] by deliberately misspelling "xanthosis". Dylan, knowing that Akeelah knows this word, intentionally misspells it as well. Dylan tells Akeelah that he wants a fair competition, rejecting his father's obsession to win. The two then proceed to spell every word listed by the judges in the hopes of winning the championship together, with Dylan earning a share of it by correctly spelling "logorrhea", much to his father's delight. Akeelah spells the last word on the list, "pulchritude", and the two are declared co-champions amidst a cheering crowd.

* [[Keke Palmer]] as Akeelah Anderson: : Three hundred girls auditioned for the role of Akeelah in Los Angeles, New York and Atlanta,{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=6}} with Palmer having auditioned five times to get the part.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5388881 |title=Keke Palmer on Bee-ing 'Akeelah' |date=May 6, 2006 |author=Berkes, Howard |publisher=[[NPR]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QU4wuIl8?url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=5388881 |archivedate=June 21, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name=rfree/> Atchison liked Palmer's acting, but the major factor in choosing her was the fact that at only age ten Palmer already had a profound interpretation of the script.<ref name=rfree>{{cite web|url=http://movies.radiofree.com/interviews/akeelaha_doug_atchison.shtml |title=Doug Atchison on 'Akeelah and the Bee' |author=Lee, Michael J. |date=April 1, 2006 |publisher=RadioFree.com |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QU2rBLmp?url=http://movies.radiofree.com/interviews/akeelaha_doug_atchison.shtml |archivedate=June 21, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> He chose her as he did not want a kid whom he would command but instead someone with whom he could have a collaboration: someone who would understand the role and "would make this character her own."{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=7}} He just assisted her to fully ensure that she would understand the character's feelings and would make "the right emotional choices."<ref name=kpbs/>
* [[Laurence Fishburne]] as Dr. Joshua Larabee: : Fishburne was pleased by the concept of the film, stating he was "really moved by it", so that he accepted to take his part "at an affordable rate", according to producer Michael Romersa.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=8}} He first read the script in 2002 and moved by the fact that "there were very few people with the courage" to "make this kind of movie"{{efn|By "this kind of movie", Fishburne was saying that ''Akeelah and the Bee'' breaks up with common stereotypes of African Americans reinforced by media. He declared, "There are no gangsters in it; there are no rappers in it. Studios are looking for an easy way to make money; [with black films], it's comedy, or it's action, or it's 'ghetto fabulous.'"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/laurence-fishburne-actor-138273 |title=ShoWest 2006 Distinguished Decade of Achievement in Film |date=March 16, 2006 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |accessdate=July 20, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6a9eL5pm4?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/laurence-fishburne-actor-138273 |archivedate=July 20, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> According to him, Hollywood "doesn't care about a young, disadvantaged black girl."<ref>{{cite * [[Angela Bassett]] as Tanya Anderson: : Bassett's agent sent her the script which she "just loved."<ref name=blackfilm>{{cite web|url=http://www.blackfilm.com/20060421/features/angelabassett.shtml |title=Akeelah and the Bee: An Interview with Angela Bassett |author=Morales, Wilson |publisher=BlackFilm.com |date=April 2006 |accessdate=June 20, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QTusNc1T?url=http://www.blackfilm.com/20060421/features/angelabassett.shtml |archivedate=June 20, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name=bassett>{{cite web |url=http://movies.about.com/od/akeelahandthebee/a/akeelahab042006.htm |title=Angela Bassett Talks About 'Akeelah and the Bee' |author=Murray, Rebecca |year=2006 |publisher=About.com |accessdate=June 17, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QPJWi45d?url=http://movies.about.com/od/akeelahandthebee/a/akeelahab042006.htm |archivedate=2014-06-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Atchison praised Bassett's portrayal of the character, asserting she "made Tanya a real person" after understanding "the thought process of the character".{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=8}} The director said Tanya wants the best for Akeelah but is reticent because she thinks "the dream will fail and make things worse."{{Sfn|Production|2006|pp=8–9}} Bassett stressed that her character has to handle the pain of her husband's death in addition to having bills paid<ref name="bassett"/> but that Tanya "gain[s] some measure of courage herself" inspired by Akeelah.<ref name=blackfilm/> * [[Curtis Armstrong]] as Bob Welch: : Atchison pointed Armstrong "was the perfect choice for the school principal." About his character role in the film, he said, "Welch is very excitable and provides a lot of the comic relief in our story."{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=9}} * J.R. Villarreal as Javier Mendez: : Villarreal was chosen by scouts at the [[Sheraton Hotels and Resorts|Sheraton Hotel]] in south [[McAllen, Texas|McAllen]] to go to the next phase in Dallas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themonitor.com/entertainment/mission-actor-kid-sister-don-t-care-who-gets-famous/article_6cf01456-b1c7-5698-98ab-2cb3321eeb65.html |title=Mission actor, kid sister don't care who gets famous first |author=Gonzalez, Sandra |date=August 12, 2009 |work=[[The Monitor (Texas)|The Monitor]] |accessdate=July 22, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aCVnC9Ao?url=http://www.themonitor.com/entertainment/mission-actor-kid-sister-don-t-care-who-gets-famous/article_6cf01456-b1c7-5698-98ab-2cb3321eeb65.html |archivedate=July 22, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> After doing well in Dallas, he was sent to auditions in California and finally got the part.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.progresstimes.net/articles/2006-05-19/Article2.htm |title=Mission Student Has Role In Major Movie |date=May 19, 2006 |work=Progress Times |accessdate=July 22, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aCWc2l4W?url=http://www.progresstimes.net/articles/2006-05-19/Article2.htm |archivedate=July 22, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> He commented that "Javier is a very good friend to Akeelah ... And also like his charisma, his character, he can always put a smile on your face. He really doesn't care what people think of him that much and he helps Akeelah out with that little matter because she cares very much of what people think about her."<ref name=villa>{{cite web |url=http://movies.about.com/od/akeelahandthebee/a/akeelahjv042406.htm |title=Interview with JR Villarreal from Akeelah and the Bee |author=Murray, Rebecca |year=2006 |publisher=About.com |accessdate=June 17, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QPKe1zh6?url=http://movies.about.com/od/akeelahandthebee/a/akeelahjv042406.htm |archivedate=June 17, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * Sean Michael Afable as Dylan Chiu: : Afable argued that his character can be "sometimes harsh and seemingly cutthroat", but this is because of the pressure his father puts on him, noting Dylan's "true character" is seen at the end of the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eeriedigest.com/wordpress/2010/10/interview-with-sean-michael-afable/ |title=Interview with Sean Michael Afable |work=The Eerie Digest |date=October 1, 2010 |accessdate=June 20, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QTr1lpYY?url=http://www.eeriedigest.com/wordpress/2010/10/interview-with-sean-michael-afable/ |archivedate=June 20, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> * Sahara Garey as Georgia Carver : Garey did "about six auditions" to take the role.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestarscoop.com/interviews/sahara-garey-exclusive-interview/ |title=Sahara Garey Exclusive Interview |publisher=The Star Scoop |date=May 29, 2006 |accessdate=June 20, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QTrU7pYw?url=http://www.thestarscoop.com/interviews/sahara-garey-exclusive-interview/ |archivedate=June 20, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> She commented that about her character: "she encourages Akeelah, because she sees so many qualities in her that she doesn't think she herself has. Georgia aims lower, but she encourages Akeelah to aim higher."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dallasblack.com/entertainment/saharagareyinterview |title=Sahara Garey: The Akeelah and the Bee Interview |author=Williams, Kam |date=May 1, 2006 |publisher=DallasBlack.com |accessdate=June 20, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QTqLi9Of?url=http://www.dallasblack.com/entertainment/saharagareyinterview |archivedate=2014-06-20 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
[[Erica Hubbard]], [[Lee Thompson Young]], and Julito McCullum portray Akeelah's sister and brothers Kiana, Devon, and Terrence, respectively.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=28}} Dalia Phillips appears as Akeelah's teacher, Ms. Cross,{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=28}}<ref name=chang>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2006/film/awards/akeelah-and-the-bee-1200517583/ |title=Review: 'Akeelah and the Bee' |author=Chang, Justin |date=March 20, 2006 |work=Variety |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6aB541yJE?url=http://variety.com/2006/film/awards/akeelah-and-the-bee-1200517583/ |archive-date =July 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> and [[Eddie Steeples]] as Derrick T.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=28}} [[Tzi Ma]] takes the role of Mr. Chiu, Dylan's father,{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=28}}<ref name=chang/> while [[Wolfgang Bodison]] plays the children's father and Tanya's husband Samuel<!-- credited only as "Akeelah's father" -->.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=28}}
==Production==
===Writing=== Doug Atchison first had the idea of making a film about spelling bees after watching the [[Scripps National Spelling Bee]] of 1994 and noticing that most of the contestants had "privileged backgrounds".{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=5}} Atchison also considered spelling bees to contain "all the drama and tension and entertainment value of a sporting event", and felt that this could be made into a film.<ref name=doug>{{cite web|url=http://movies.about.com/od/akeelahandthebee/a/akeelahda042406.htm |title=Interview with 'Akeelah and the Bee' Writer/Director Doug Atchison |author=Murray, Rebecca |year=2006 |publisher=About.com |accessdate=June 17, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QPMGnSL2?url=http://movies.about.com/od/akeelahandthebee/a/akeelahda042406.htm |archivedate=June 17, 2014 |deadurl=no |pp=1–2 |df= }}</ref><ref name=studlife>{{cite web|url=http://www.studlife.com/archives/Cadenza/2006/04/07/AkeelahandtheBeeAnInterviewwithDougAtchison/ |title=Akeelah and the Bee: An Interview with Doug Atchison |author=Stitt, Brian |date=April 7, 2006 |work=[[Student Life (newspaper)|Student Life]] |publisher=[[Washington University in St. Louis]] |accessdate=June 18, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QPafZYYE?url=http://www.studlife.com/archives/Cadenza/2006/04/07/AkeelahandtheBeeAnInterviewwithDougAtchison/ |archivedate=June 18, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> From this, he got the idea to write a script following the story of a child who had talent for spelling bee but was from a low-income neighborhood so did not "have access to the resources or coaching to pursue it as these other kids had."<ref name=kpbs/>{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=5}} He had the desire of making a "''[[Rocky]]''-like story" and although made it a "dramatic" plot, he declared it is "essentially a sports movie".<ref name=kpbs/>
Atchison started his screenplay in 1999, when he wrote a five-page [[Film treatment|treatment]] in about a month.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=5}}<ref name=doug/> In addition to the fact he was working on other projects, Atchison said he waited years before starting to write because he "thought someone else would do it first." This did not happen, so he began to write by himself.<ref name=studlife/> Few changes were made in the process of transitioning from the original draft to the final product. One change was that at first, Akeelah's mother had a smaller role and Akeelah's father was alive. Also, Larabee had been an older man (72 years old), and a few characters were cut. However, Atchison has summarized that "the steps she goes through, the friends she's got, those were always the same."<ref name=doug/>
===Development=== In 2000, Atchison submitted his script to the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] along with about 4,500 others, in hopes of winning the [[Nicholl Fellowships in Screenwriting]]. Atchison's script ended up being one of five scripts selected, and he won the grant.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=5}}<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/nicholl/fellows/1986-present.html | title=Academy Nicholl Fellows 1986–Present | publisher=Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences | accessdate=June 17, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302233824/http://oscars.org/awards/nicholl/fellows/1986-present.html | archivedate=March 2, 2009}}</ref> Editor [[Glenn Farr]], then a member of the committee, offered to edit Atchison's film as soon as it was finished.<ref name=cc/> Producer [[Sid Ganis]] was also attracted to the story during the award presentation ceremony.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=5}} [[Nancy Hult Ganis]], Sid's wife who was interested in public education, encouraged him to follow through with the film.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=6}}
The film was produced by [[Lionsgate Films]], [[2929 Entertainment]], [[Starbucks Entertainment]], Out of the Blue Entertainment, Reactor Films and Cinema Gypsy Productions,{{efn|name=companies}} with a budget around $6–8 million.<ref name=ppgaz/><ref name=box/> However, the Ganis couple found it difficult to secure funding for the film.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=6}} In August 2001, Danny Llewelyn's Panoptic Pictures acquired the rights of Atchison's script.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2001/film/news/panoptic-buzzes-to-bee-1117851262/ |title=Panoptic buzzes to 'Bee' |author=Swanson, Tim |date=August 14, 2001 |work=Variety |publisher=Penske Media Corporation |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aCQdEfUX?url=http://variety.com/2001/film/news/panoptic-buzzes-to-bee-1117851262/ |archivedate=July 22, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> In 2002<!-- <ref name=wpost/><ref name=austinc/> -->, documentary ''[[Spellbound (2002 film)|Spellbound]]'' was released and attracted attention to spelling bees, which, according to Hult Ganis, "helped us in some way".{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=6}} In November 2004, Lionsgate Films announced they would fund and distribute the film;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.backstage.com/news/lions-gate-gets-busy-on-bee-drama/ |title=Lions Gate Gets Busy on 'Bee' Drama |author=Foreman, Liza |date=November 30, 2004 |work=[[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage]] |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aCTbTVHd?url=http://www.backstage.com/news/lions-gate-gets-busy-on-bee-drama/ |archivedate=July 22, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> and in collaboration with 2929 Entertainment they would co-finance the production.<ref name=bonnet>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2004/film/features/lions-gate-puts-bee-in-its-bonnet-1117914121/ |title=Lions Gate puts 'Bee' in its bonnet |author=Dunkley, Cathy |date=November 29, 2004 |work=Variety |publisher=Penske Media Corporation |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aB8JwN8P?url=http://variety.com/2004/film/features/lions-gate-puts-bee-in-its-bonnet-1117914121/ |archivedate=July 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> In January 2006, Starbucks announced a partnership with Lionsgate to market it.<ref name=starbucks/>
Another factor in not having a studio attached before was Atchison's desire to direct it as he wanted to ensure his story would remain the one he envisioned. Several studios wanted to turn Larabee's character into a white character but Atchison felt "it was important that Akeelah's mentor be someone that comes from her neighborhood, that looks like her."<ref name=kpbs>{{cite web|url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2006/may/04/akeelah-and-the-bee/ |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Accomando, Beth |date=May 4, 2006 |publisher=KPBS |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aBtNP9m4?url=http://www.kpbs.org/news/2006/may/04/akeelah-and-the-bee/ |archivedate=July 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Lionsgate's President of Production Michael Paseornek agreed that Atchison should direct the script, claiming that he was the only person who could do it because the story "was in his heart and in his mind".{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=6}}
===Filming=== Filming began in February 2005;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2005/film/markets-festivals/bassett-on-bee-spree-1117916235/ |title=Bassett on 'Bee' spree |date=January 12, 2005 |author=Dunkley, Cathy |work=Variety |publisher=Penske Media Corporation |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aCiYfp8a?url=http://variety.com/2005/film/markets-festivals/bassett-on-bee-spree-1117916235/ |archivedate=July 22, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> the crew filmed for ten hours a day for thirty-one days.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=9}}<ref name=doug/> The eleven-year-old Palmer had to follow the United States' [[child labor laws in the United States|child labor laws]], which necessitated spending at least three hours a day at school, one on recreation, and one at lunch.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=9}}<ref name=doug/> Nevertheless, Palmer appeared in almost every scene, about which Ganis commented, "I honestly don't know how we figured it out, but we did".{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=9}} To get the filming done on time, Atchison storyboarded the scenes ahead of time and chatted with cinematographer [[M. David Mullen|David Mullen]], the production designer Warren Young, and Glenn Farr to compile a list of scenes.<ref name=doug/> This way, the filming team began each day knowing what shots they would take, their order, and the performances scheduled for each day.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=9}}<ref name=doug/> Most of the filming took place in [[South Los Angeles]],{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=9}} which Atchison picked as the filming location due to their low budget.<ref name=rfree/> Scenes were also filmed at the [[University of Southern California]], [[Hollywood Palladium]]—which stood in for the Grand Ballroom of the Washington, D.C. Hyatt Hotel—and [[Venice High School (Los Angeles)|Venice High School]].{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=10}}
===Authenticity=== To bring authenticity to the film's portrayal of spelling bees, George Hornedo, who competed in spelling bees in real life, was hired to play contestant Roman and be "an unofficial technical consultant." Hornedo helped the actors to recreate "certain habits and idiosyncrasies they do on stage to help them spell."{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=10}} Thus, Akeelah skipping rope to memorize the words was added as "something that was normal for the spelling bee" but Atchison tried to create it in a "subtle" way as he thought the audience could consider this unrealistic.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://movies.about.com/od/akeelahandthebee/a/akeelahkp042006.htm |title=Keke Palmer Steals the Show in Akeelah and the Bee |author=Murray, Rebecca |year=2006 |publisher=About.com |accessdate=June 17, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QPJ2PX6b?url=http://movies.about.com/od/akeelahandthebee/a/akeelahkp042006.htm |archivedate=2014-06-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Hornedo and other children who had never acted before were cast because of their authentic portrayals of nervous contestants; other kids, in Atchison's eyes, were "too old in how they acted".<ref name=studlife/> Also, [[Jacques Bailly]], who won the Scripps National Spelling Bee in 1980 and is currently the contest's official pronouncer, since 2003, played himself in the film.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://content.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,1900587,00.html | title=Spelling Bee Pronouncer Jacques Bailly | author=Stephey, M.J. | date=May 26, 2009 | work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | accessdate=May 26, 2016}}</ref>
To further help the staff, Atchison asked Paige Kimball, director of the Scripps National Spelling Bee, to be a consultant. Kimball "was amazed at not only at how precise it was in its recreation, but also how authentic the individuals and the casting for the event was."{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=10}} However, she and the organization did have some disagreements. Atchison has admitted that he originally created a more dramatic story than she wanted. However, he believed most of the disagreements were about technical procedures, "things you wouldn't even notice". For example, the children were originally sponsored by newspapers to compete, but Atchison felt this detail did not improve the story, so he removed it. There were some concerns about the screenplay, and Atchison changed some of them "because [he] thought it didn't matter one way or another so [he] just made them happy."<ref name=doug/>
===Music=== The film features a musical score by [[Aaron Zigman]], who wrote 45 minutes of compositions in two and a half weeks. He had planned to score ''Akeelah and the Bee'' over the holidays, but Lionsgate pushed its release date up, so Zigman was pressed for time to write the score.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soundtrack.net/content/article/?id=219 |title=Aaron Zigman - Interview |author=Goldwasser, Dan |date=February 2007 |publisher=[[Soundtrack.Net]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QWYG3XLF?url=http://www.soundtrack.net/content/article/?id=219 |archivedate=June 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> He drew inspiration from Fishburne's performance to write it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inmag.com/music/aaron-zigman.html |title=An Interview With Aaron Zigman |author=Tran, Kim |work=In Magazine |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QWYU4iDv?url=http://www.inmag.com/music/aaron-zigman.html |archivedate=June 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> A soundtrack album consisting of 16 tracks was released by Lionsgate Records in a deal with [[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]]'s [[RED Distribution]] on April 4, 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soundtrack.net/album/akeelah-and-the-bee/ |title=Akeelah and the Bee Soundtrack (2006) |publisher=Soundtrack.Net |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QWYeaQqP?url=http://www.soundtrack.net/album/akeelah-and-the-bee/ |archivedate=June 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_RUEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA22#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=Lionsgate's New Tracks | author=Martens, Todd | journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | date=April 15, 2006 | issue=15 | volume=118 | page=22}}</ref> It peaked at number 193 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], and reached the 19th and sixth spot on the [[Billboard Top Independent Albums|''Billboard'' Top Independent Albums]] and Top Soundtracks respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/akeelah-and-the-bee-original-soundtrack-mw0000533256/awards |title=Akeelah and the Bee [Original Soundtrack] - Original Soundtrack − Awards |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QWYwjVNP?url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/akeelah-and-the-bee-original-soundtrack-mw0000533256/awards |archivedate=June 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The original score, consisting of 37 tracks, was also released on April 4 as an [[iTunes]] exclusive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soundtrack.net/album/akeelah-and-the-bee-original-score/ |title=Akeelah and the Bee - Original Score (2006) |publisher=Soundtrack.Net |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QWYgIpbi?url=http://www.soundtrack.net/album/akeelah-and-the-bee-original-score/ |archivedate=June 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mania.com/lionsgate-releases-tylers-bug-score-online_article_54690.html |title=Lionsgate releases Tyler's BUG score online |author=Larson, Randall |date=May 18, 2007 |publisher=Mania.com |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QWYqGTAn?url=http://www.mania.com/lionsgate-releases-tylers-bug-score-online_article_54690.html |archivedate=June 22, 2014}}</ref>
==Themes and analysis== {{rquote|right|If you see African-American kids striving to do something in the movies, it's sports or singing or dancing. Here, we're engaging kids on their intellect. That, you don't see. These lies about black inferiority have been seeping into cinema, and that seeps into our kids. As a filmmaker, you can dig into these issues |Doug Atchison<ref name=ppgaz/>}}
Commentators on ''Akeelah and the Bee'' opined it dealt with multiple themes, including race{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=18}} and racism,<ref name=filmcritic>{{cite web | url=http://www.filmcritic.com/misc/emporium.nsf/reviews/Akeelah-and-the-Bee | title=Akeelah and the Bee | author=Gordon, Rachel | date=April 27, 2006 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021013407/http://www.filmcritic.com/misc/emporium.nsf/reviews/Akeelah-and-the-Bee | archivedate=October 21, 2007 | website=Filmcritic.com | accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref> poverty,{{sfn|Niemiec|Wedding|2013|p=65}} educational system,<ref name=turan/><ref name=austinc/> competition and sportsmanship,<ref name=austinc/><ref name=ebert/> self-esteem,{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=25-26}} [[self-image]],<ref name=independent/> stigma,<ref name=turan/> community,<ref name=turan/><ref name=wpost/> friendship,<ref name=utsd/> gender{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=18}} and sexism,{{sfn|Niemiec|Wedding|2013|p=65}} age,{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=18}} [[social class|class]]<ref name=nypress>{{cite web|url=http://www.nypress.com/bee-season/ |title=Bee Season |date=May 3, 2006 |work=New York Press |publisher=Straus News |accessdate=July 29, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aNDquRXh?url=http://www.nypress.com/bee-season/ |archivedate=July 29, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> and classism,<ref name=filmcritic/> and [[empowerment]].<ref name=turan/> Atchison affirmed that its focus is not the spelling but "a kid who learns what she's good at, becomes proud of that and doesn't want to hide it anymore. It's overcoming the fear of being great, before you can be great."{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=11}} Sid Ganis described it as a film "about hope and doing great things against all the odds,"{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=6}} while a ''[[New York Press]]'' reviewer declared it "addresses the human condition".<ref name=nypress/>
After attending USC School of Cinematic Arts and working at a youth center in South Los Angeles,<ref name=doug/> Atchison incorporated his experiences from the neighborhood into the film; among them, he heard that children who do well in school are said to be "[[acting white]]". As a result, Atchison tried to use the film to show what causes these children to doubt their own abilities.<ref name=studlife/> These doubts are shown through the preconceptions Akeelah and other community members have that "Spelling Bee is for someone else".<ref name=bonnet/> She "must first overcome her feelings of inadequacy,"<ref name=bonnet/> and when she discovers Larabee comes from her neighborhood and is a successful man, it "empowers her to ... accomplish this task."{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=6}} Fishburne stated the film's treatment of race extends beyond the dichotomy of struggle and success, and goes into the prejudice that many people hold against black people competing in mainstream society. Atchison elaborated, "it's about this girl's insecurity about doing a thing that she hasn't seen people who look like her doing".<ref name=ppgaz/> The director affirmed that African American children in film usually aspire to nothing other than being successful in sports, music or dance. He argued that the film industry has disseminated "lies about black inferiority", so he was interested in focusing on their intellect rather than let them succumb to the stereotypes. Atchison noted he had created the project for all audiences "but particularly for kids [[person of color|of color]] to see a little black girl who does something powerful."<ref name=ppgaz/>
The director also attributed Akeelah's low-esteem and doubt of her own capacities to the public school system, where she is bullied and "her intellectual curiosity is kind of crushed".<ref name=kpbs/> As such, Akeelah is portrayed as an "undermotivated student",<ref name=chang/> who "[u]nwilling to be stigmatized as a freak or a brainiac," avoids showing her abilities.<ref name=turan/> According to Wesley Morris of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', the film shows "the contradiction gifted students feel in an inhospitable environment."<ref name=morris/> Ann Hornaday from ''[[The Washington Post]]'' opined that Akeelah's sentence "Why would I want to represent a school that doesn't even have doors on the toilets?" is "one of the film's many subtle critiques of the country's education policies."<ref name=wpost/> Writing in the ''[[English Journal]]'', Amanda L. Hodges said it suggests a new approach on teaching with the "50,000 coaches" part; she declared it deconstructs the image of teachers "as those who keep order and disseminate knowledge" and shows that "[t]eaching is not an isolated activity that begins and ends at the classroom door."<ref name=hodges>{{cite journal | title=A Critical Close-Up: Three Films and Their Lessons in Critical Literacy | author=Hodges, Amanda L. | journal=English Journal | publisher=[[National Council of Teachers of English]] | volume=99 | issue=3 | date=January 2010 | page=73 | doi=10.2307/40503486}}</ref>
Villarreal commented that the film "teaches you not to let your friends down",<ref name=utsd/> while Fishburne believed that the theme of community was important.{{Sfn|Production|2006|p=8}} Marrit Ingman of ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' said the film indicates "a community-based, cooperative model of group success,"<ref name=austinc/> while Justin Chang of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' said it "focuses ... on the bee's community-uniting impact."<ref name=chang/> Hodges said Akeelah goes to the spelling bee because she recognizes it "proves that someone from their neighborhood can achieve success, and her achievement is, in a real sense, their own".<ref name=hodges/> In contrast, Bernard Beck wrote for ''Multicultural Perspectives'' that it depicts "the success of individual perseverance",{{sfn|Beck|2009|p=149}} while ''Red Feather Journall''{{'}}s Kathryn Linder expressed a similar opinion about individual success.{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=24}} Nevertheless, [[Kenneth Turan]] of the ''Los Angeles Times'' commented "it raises important points about the ... obstacles to success that kids from poor neighborhoods face."<ref name=turan/> The ''New York Press''{{'}}s reviewer went further and said social class was its "real subject" as it "depicts the basics of class mobility that are routinely taken for granted".<ref name=nypress/> However, Chang asserted it shows the spelling bee contest as "a democratizing force",<ref name=chang/> while Rob Asghar, for ''[[The Seattle Times]]'', wrote it treats English as "the quintessential American tool for success."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20060518&slug=asghar18 |title=One nation, one anthem, sung in our common tongue |author=Ashgar, Rob |date=May 18, 2006 |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aTAUTzk9?url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20060518&slug=asghar18 |archivedate=August 2, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Both Fishburne and Bassett also remarked that an important message of ''Akeelah and the Bee'' is to "speak properly" rather than strictly in vernacular, although Bassett emphasized the importance of the film's themes beyond spelling and spelling bees.<ref name=radiofree/><ref name=bassett/> Atchison added that beyond learning how to spell words, Akeelah must learn the importance of the words. He said that Larabee "looks at Akeelah as a potential leader. He wants her to understand her history. She needs to know the importance of language – and competition."<ref name=studlife/> In spite of knowing its importance, it "deconstruct[s] the 'competition' paradigm of learning", according to Ingman.<ref name=austinc/> Fishburne noted not only children but parents can learn from the film; in his opinion, the most important is that they should pay attention to their children's abilities.<ref name=radiofree/> Villarreal also felt that, through Dylan's father, parents would be able to ponder if they are "push[ing] their kids to follow their own dreams and not the children's dreams."<ref name=villa/>
==Release and reception==
===Marketing and release=== The film was promoted by coffee shop chain [[Starbucks]] as a result of a partnership between [[Lions Gate Entertainment]] and Starbucks Entertainment.<ref name=csprev>{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/weekendwarrior/2006/apr28.php |title=Your Weekly Guide to New Movies for April 28, 2006 |date=April 28, 2006 |author=Douglas, Edward |publisher=[[CraveOnline]] |work=ComingSoon.net |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QWZ6kmSd?url=http://www.comingsoon.net/weekendwarrior/2006/apr28.php |archivedate=June 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> In January 2006, approximately 8,300 Starbucks locations in the United States and Canada began a promotional campaign for the film involving spelling-related trivia games and promotions on cardboard cup sleeves.<ref name=starbucks>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/13/business/13starbucks.html |title=Starbucks to Add Movie Products |date=January 13, 2006 |author=[[Bloomberg News]] |work=The New York Times |accessdate=May 20, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv1Tc2C2?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2006/01/13/business/13starbucks.html?_r=0 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2006/film/markets-festivals/inside-move-grounds-for-bee-blurbs-1117940825/ |title=Inside Move: Grounds for 'Bee' blurbs |date=April 3, 2006 |author=McClintock, Pamela |work=Variety |publisher=Penske Media Corporation |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aBBX2sca?url=http://variety.com/2006/film/markets-festivals/inside-move-grounds-for-bee-blurbs-1117940825/ |archivedate=July 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' stated that Lionsgate spent around $20 million with its market only,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2007/film/news/rough-start-for-starbucks-1117970763/ |title=Rough start for Starbucks |author=Graser, Marc |date=August 23, 2007 |work=Variety |publisher=Penske Media Corporation |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QWbexFsU?url=http://variety.com/2007/film/news/rough-start-for-starbucks-1117970763/ |archivedate=June 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> while ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' reported a $25 million cost to both produce and market the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/aug/27/business/fi-starbucks27 |title=Disappointing bean counters |date=August 27, 2007 |author1=Friedman, Josh |author2=Munoz, Lorenza |work=Los Angeles Times |publisher=[[Tribune Publishing]] |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QWcn93pi?url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/aug/27/business/fi-starbucks27 |archivedate=June 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> [[Ford Motor Company]] also sponsored the film by providing a [[Lincoln MKZ|Lincoln Zephyr]] to chauffeur the cast and creators to and from a screening.<ref name=zephyr/>
''Akeelah and the Bee'' was first shown at the 2006 [[ShoWest]] on March 14,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ti-highlights-advancement-of-digital-cinema-industry-at-showest-55323882.html |title=TI Highlights Advancement of Digital Cinema Industry at ShoWest |date=March 13, 2006 |publisher=PR Newswire |accessdate=July 21, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> and later premiered as the opening film at the 30th [[Cleveland International Film Festival]] on March 16.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clevelandmagazine.com/ME2/dirmod.asp?sid=E73ABD6180B44874871A91F6BA5C249C&nm=&type=Publishing&mod=Publications::Article&mid=1578600D80804596A222593669321019&tier=4&id=51D50CFA83914A0E984A7F26B87E326C |archivedate=July 21, 2015 }}</ref> On April 20, the film was screened at [[The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] in Beverly Hills,<ref name=zephyr>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/lincoln-zephyr-rolls-out-red-carpet-for-premiere-of-lionsgates-akeelah-and-the-bee-56469932.html |title=Lincoln Zephyr Rolls Out Red Carpet for Premiere Services |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6QWjGn3mG?url=http://www.the-numbers.com/interactive/newsStory.php?newsID=1871 |archivedate=June 22, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> With predictions of strong box office returns by film critics,<ref name=csprev/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/interactive/newsStory.php?newsID=1834 |title=2006 Preview: April |author=Strowbridge, C.S. |date=April 1, 2006 |work=The Numbers |publisher=Nash Information Services |accessdate=May 10, 2014 as well financially as they had predicted,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.totalfilm.com/news/rv-drives-the-us-box-office |title=RV drives the US box office |date=May 2, 2006 |work=[[Total Film]] Outside the United States, the film debuted at the Sprockets Toronto International Film Festival for Children on April 23, 2006,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.e.bell.ca/filmfest/sprockets/schedule.asp | title=Schedule & Special Events |
