url=http://www.cambridgefilmfestival.org.uk/cgi-bin/film-view.cgi?filmid=690 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060930013626/http://www.cambridgefilmfestival.org.uk/cgi-bin/film-view.cgi?filmid=690<!-- alternative: https://www.webcitation.org/6aCaIFJcg?url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060930013626/http://www.cambridgefilmfestival.org.uk/cgi-bin/film-view.cgi?filmid%3D690 --> | archivedate=September 30, 2006 | title=Akeelah and the Bee | publisher=Cambridge Film Festival | accessdate=July 22, 2015}}</ref><!-- if some third-party source is required: http://www.bbc.co.uk/cambridgeshire/content/articles/2006/07/26/cambs_film_festival_06_young_jury_reviews_feature.shtml --> and it premiered in the British theaters on August 18.<ref name=bbc/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/film-and-tv/film-review-akeelah-and-the-bee-12a-1038995 |title=Film review: Akeelah and the Bee (12A) | date=April 17, 2010 |work=[[Manchester Evening News]] |publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]] |accessdate=July 22, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aCdLkjHp?url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/film-and-tv/film-review-akeelah-and-the-bee-12a-1038995 |archivedate=July 22, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The film was also screened in October 2006 at the [[Rome Film Festival]], in which it competed at the Alicy in the City section.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2006/film/markets-festivals/rome-fest-mixes-flavors-1117950737/ |title=Rome fest mixes flavors |date=September 26, 2006 |author=Vivarelli, Nick |work=Variety |publisher=Penske Media Corporation |accessdate=July 22, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aCgkGFRF?url=http://variety.com/2006/film/markets-festivals/rome-fest-mixes-flavors-1117950737/ |archivedate=July 22, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
===Home media=== The film was released on DVD by [[Lionsgate Home Entertainment]] on August 29, 2006, becoming the first [[DVD]] offered for sale at Starbucks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.videobusiness.com/article/CA6340569.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5j7VkJQ72?url=http://www.videobusiness.com/article/CA6340569.html |title=Starbucks rocks with Berry DVD |author=Ault, Susanne |accessdate=August 18, 2009 |archivedate=August 18, 2009 |date=June 2, 2006 |work=Video Business |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] }}</ref> Its bonus features on the single-disc DVD include seven deleted scenes and a 25-minute making-of video featuring Atchinson and the cast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/reviews/?id=2054 |title=Movie Review: Akeelah and the Bee |work=Box Office Mojo |publisher=Amazon.com |author=Holleran, Scott | year=2006 |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv4bynsp?url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/reviews/?id=2054 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> DVD sales in the United States reached $5,391,947 as 317,942 copies were sold after one week on sale. By December 2006, American consumers had spent a total of $25,855,396 to purchase 1,512,498 copies,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2006/AKELA-DVD.php |title=Akeelah and the Bee – DVD Sales |work=The Numbers |publisher=Nash Information Services |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv4iEEtx?url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2006/AKELA-DVD.php |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> making it one of the three most profitable home video releases of Lionsgate in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/revenues-boost-lionsgate-q3-earnings-129908 |title=Revenues boost Lionsgate Q3 earnings |author=Vlessing, Etan | date=February 2, 2007 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |accessdate=July 20, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6a9h57BvJ?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/revenues-boost-lionsgate-q3-earnings-129908 |archivedate=July 20, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
===Critical reaction=== [[File:Keke Palmer.jpg|thumb|Keke Palmer's portrayal of Akeelah was highly praised by critics, with one saying she "[stole the] movie from Angela Bassett and Laurence Fishburne".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?slug=akeelah28&date=20060428 |title=Akeelah and the Bee": Young star casts quite a spell in busy, busy "Bee |date=April 28, 2006 |author=Macdonald, Moira |work=The Seattle Times |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv8ewljI?url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?slug=akeelah28&date=20060428 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Palmer's performance led her to win several awards, including a [[Black Movie Awards|Black Movie Award]], a [[Black Reel Awards|Black Reel Award]], a [[NAACP Image Award]], and a [[Young Artist Award]].<ref name=bma/><ref name=bra/><ref name=image/><ref name=young/>]]
The film received generally positive reviews from [[film criticism|film critic]]s. The [[review aggregator]] website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports an 84% approval rating based on 138 reviews, with an average rating of 7.1/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "A warm, family-friendly underdog story, featuring terrific supporting performances from Keke Palmer, Laurence Fishburne, and Angela Bassett."<ref name=rt>{{cite web | url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/akeelah_and_the_bee | title = Akeelah and the Bee (2006) | accessdate=August 30, 2017 | work=Rotten Tomatoes | publisher=[[Flixster]]}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has an average weighted score of 72 out 100, based on 30 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/akeelah-and-the-bee | title=Akeelah and the Bee | publisher=[[Metacritic]] | accessdate=May 10, 2014}}</ref> [[CinemaScore]] reported that audiences gave the film a rare<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=89927 |title=The Avengers Makes $80.5 Million Its Opening Day! |publisher=CraveOnline |work=ComingSoon.net |date=May 5, 2012 |accessdate=May 5, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67RRbeYXL?url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=89927 |archivedate=May 5, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> average grade of "A+".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-cinemascore-matters-box-office-225563 |title=Why CinemaScore Matters for Box Office |author=McClintock, Pamela |date=August 19, 2011 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6PTUrtDVN?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-cinemascore-matters-box-office-225563 |archivedate=May 10, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
[[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' wrote it is "an uncommonly good movie, entertaining and actually inspirational".<ref name=ebert>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/akeelah-and-the-bee-2006 |date=April 27, 2006 |author=Ebert, Roger |accessdate=May 16, 2011 |publisher=rogerebert.com |title=Akeelah and the Bee Review (2006) |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv5vriYG?url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/akeelah-and-the-bee-2006 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Writing for ''[[Film Journal International]]'', Doris Toumarkine praised its pace and how "Atchison takes spelling competitions and conveys the excitement of the 'sport,' the appeal of the 'game,' the thrill of the win, [and] the crushing blow of the loss."<ref name=filmj>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002383630 |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Toumarkine, Doris |date=April 20, 2006 |work=Film Journal International |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |accessdate=June 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv5xIVy1?url=http://www.filmjournal.com/filmjournal/esearch/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1002383630 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Hornaday from ''The Washington Post'' called the film "a triumph on many levels" and proclaimed, "It's that nod to the collective ... that makes ''Akeelah and the Bee'' so special." She especially appreciated that South Los Angeles was presented without stereotypes.<ref name=wpost>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/27/AR2006042702373.html |title='Akeelah and the Bee': One Honey of a Flick |author=Hornaday, Ann |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The Washington Post |publisher=Nash Holdings |accessdate=June 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv5wiKzS?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/04/27/AR2006042702373.html |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Jane Clifford of ''[[U-T San Diego]]'' felt the film would appeal to both children and adults, and stated that every time she tried to predict its plot "it took a sharp turn. A turn that leaves you facing your stereotypes and feeling a little sheepish."<ref name=utsd>{{cite web|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20060429/news_1c29clifford.html |title='Akeelah' a letter-perfect feel-good family film |author=Clifford, Jane |date=April 29, 2006 |work=U-T San Diego |publisher=[[Copley Newspapers]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv6QrfgZ?url=http://www.utsandiego.com/uniontrib/20060429/news_1c29clifford.html |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> [[Dana Stevens (critic)|Dana Stevens]], writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', asserted, "The innate suspense and charm of the spelling bee," and "a trio of crack performances" can turn "a formulaic sports picture" into a "tale that manages to inspire without being sappy."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://movies2.nytimes.com/2006/04/28/movies/28akee.html |title=A Young Girl and Big Words in 'Akeelah and the Bee' |author=Stevens, Dana |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7519ZX?url=http://movies2.nytimes.com/2006/04/28/movies/28akee.html |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Shantayaé Grant of ''[[The Jamaica Observer]]'' wrote that "acting is spectacular, the emotions are real and this story of black triumph is simply phenomenal."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/teenage/Black-History-in-Movies_13545736 |title=Black History in Movies |date=February 5, 2013 |work=The Jamaica Observer |accessdate=August 2, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130214000934/http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/teenage/Black-History-in-Movies_13545736 |archivedate=February 14, 2013 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> ''New York Press'' critic affirmed that ''Akeelah and the Bee'' "resurrects a nearly lost idea of what an art-movie really is" because it has "dramatic attention to character and place, psychology and existence."<ref name=nypress/>
Chang of ''Variety'' commented that it "plays like ''[[The Karate Kid]]'' with a pro-literacy agenda, pushing all the right emotional buttons yet hitting quite a few wrong ones in the process."<ref name=chang/> The ''[[Evening Chronicle]]''{{'}}s review said it "conceals few narrative surprises" but contended that "when [Atchison] does finally defy our expectations, it's to ensure his spellers learn a valuable lesson about integrity."<ref name=chronicle>{{cite web|url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/whats-on/film-tv/akeelah-and-the-bee-1545750 |title=Akeelah and the Bee |date=August 18, 2006 |work=Evening Chronicle |accessdate=June 10, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv6LUmqF?url=http://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/whats-on/film-tv/akeelah-and-the-bee-1545750 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Turan of the ''Los Angeles Times'' criticized that the film "telegraphs its plot"; however, he praised it as "genuinely sweet and determinedly inspirational."<ref name=turan>{{cite web|url=http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/turan/cl-et-akeelah28apr28,0,6385780.story |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060829024947/http://www.calendarlive.com/movies/turan/cl-et-akeelah28apr28%2C0%2C6385780.story |archivedate=August 29, 2006 |title=Movie Review - 'Akeelah and the Bee' |date=April 28, 2006 |author=Turan, Kenneth |work=Los Angeles Times |publisher=Tribune Publishing |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> ''[[PopMatters]]''{{'}}s Cynthia Fuchs stated it is formulaic as it has some "conventions that make so many other genre films feel stale," but that it "torques them slightly", emphasizing the "intellectual activities" Akeelah gets involved with.<ref name=fuchs>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/akeelah_and_the_bee_2006/ |title=Akeelah and the Bee (2006) |author=Fuchs, Cynthia |date=April 28, 2006 |work=PopMatters |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv6P7c2g?url=http://www.popmatters.com/review/akeelah_and_the_bee_2006/ |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Furthermore, the film was described as "derivatively entertaining in a feel-good sort of way" by Rick Groen in an article for ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/Page/document/v5/content/subscribe?user_URL=https://www.theglobeandmail.com%2Fservlet%2Fstory%2FLAC.20060428.BEE28%2FTPStory%2FTPEntertainment%2F&ord=14321757&brand=theglobeandmail&force_login=true |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080204080758/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/Page/document/v5/content/subscribe?user_URL=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.theglobeandmail.com%2Fservlet%2Fstory%2FLAC.20060428.BEE28%2FTPStory%2FTPEntertainment%2F&ord=14321757&brand=theglobeandmail&force_login=true |archivedate=February 4, 2008 |title=A star shines in a bee movie |author=Groen, Rick |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The Globe and Mail |publisher=[[CTVglobemedia]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Ingman of ''The Austin Chronicle'' described it as a typical sports film and felt it was heavy-handed at times. However, she praised it for its themes and called the film a "[t]houghtful, engaging," one and said it has "cross-gender appeal".<ref name=austinc>{{cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/calendar/film/2006-04-28/360512/ |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Ingman, Marrit |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The Austin Chronicle |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv6oSl2Q?url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/calendar/film/2006-04-28/360512/ |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Morris of ''The Boston Globe'' argued, "If ''Akeelah and the Bee'' is a generic, well-oiled commercial contraption, it is the first to credibly dramatize the plight of a truly gifted, poor black child." Morris added, "Obviously, it's emotional propaganda. But it's just the kind of propaganda our children need."<ref name=morris>{{cite web|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2006/04/28/in_a_word_akeelah_spells_crowd_pleaser/ |title=In a word, 'Akeelah' spells crowd-pleaser |author=Morris, Wesley |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The Boston Globe |publisher=Boston Globe Media Partners |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv79ILgK?url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2006/04/28/in_a_word_akeelah_spells_crowd_pleaser/ |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Despite being a "critically acclaimed" film, according to Rotten Tomatoes,<ref name=rt/> not all of its reviews were this positive. Anna Smith of ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' called it "formulaic and all-American", commenting that many scenes "appear functional rather than inspirational", and that the film focused on the racial issue "a little too heavily". Smith stated, "clunky plotting and characterisation mean it has 'telemovie' written all over it."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=134416 |title=Akeelah And The Bee Review |author=Smith, Anna |date=March 26, 2007 |work=Empire |publisher=[[Bauer Media Group]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7Vf6h1?url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=134416 |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Marc Mohan from ''[[The Oregonian]]'' stressed it can be compared to [[after-school special]]s due to its "lack of originality in plot and character."<ref name=oregon>{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/entertainment/1146088530229920.xml&coll=7 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070111214847/http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/oregonian/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fentertainment%2F1146088530229920.xml&coll=7 |title=Akeelah and the B movie |archivedate=January 11, 2007 |date=April 28, 2006 |work=The Oregonian |author=Mohan, Marc |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]''{{'}}s Jessica Winter also drew a comparation to after-school specials, saying "on the big screen ... its clichés seem bigger and its characterisations broader than they would on the more forgiving telly."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/film/akeelah-and-the-bee |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Winter, Jessica |date=August 17, 2006 |work=Time Out |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7YTNFy?url=http://www.timeout.com/london/film/akeelah-and-the-bee |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Nick Schager of ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' lamented that the "clichés are too numerous to mention",<ref name=slant>{{cite web | url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/Film/film_review.asp?ID=2164 | title=Film Review: Akeelah and the Bee | author=Schager, Nick | work=Slant Magazine | date=April 21, 2006 | accessdate=June 21, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070804075926/http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/film_review.asp?ID=2164 | archivedate=August 4, 2007}}</ref> while Neil Smith from [[BBC]] asserted it has "as much ... fantasy as ''[[Lord of the Rings]]''."<ref name=bbc>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/films/2006/08/09/akeelah_and_the_bee_2006_review.shtml |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Smith, Neil |date=August 14, 2006 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7uuhQQ?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/films/2006/08/09/akeelah_and_the_bee_2006_review.shtml |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Jan Stuart of ''[[Newsday]]'' deemed it "virtually suspense-free,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/movies/ny-etmovie4718457apr28,0,5719140.story?coll=ny-moviereview-headlines |title=Sting of defeat for 'Bee' is the plot |author=Stuart, Jan |date=April 28, 2006 |work=Newsday |publisher=[[Cablevision]] |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327231715/http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/movies/ny-etmovie4718457apr28%2C0%2C5719140.story?coll=ny-moviereview-headlines |archivedate=2008-03-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> while Robert Hanks of ''[[The Independent]]'' stated it has an important message but that is a "shame it couldn't be encased in a less faked-up story".<ref name=independent>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/akeelah-and-the-bee-12a--none-onestar-twostar-threestar-fourstar-fivestar-412273.html |title=Akeelah and the Bee (12A) |author=Hanks, Robert |date=August 18, 2006 |work=The Independent |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aT5Y7rZa?url=http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/akeelah-and-the-bee-12a--none-onestar-twostar-threestar-fourstar-fivestar-412273.html |archivedate=August 1, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Commenting on ''[[The Times]]'', [[Chris Ayres]] stressed that although it has good "visual flair" it "is ruined by its ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show|Oprah]]''-style [[emotional manipulation]]."<ref>{{cite news | title=A spell of good fortune | author=Ayres, Chris | work=The Times | date=August 17, 2006 | publisher=[[News UK]] | pages=18–19 (''Times2'' supplement)}}</ref> ''[[New York Post]]''{{'}}s [[Kyle Smith]] deemed it as "uplifting but unimaginative", suggesting that "''Akeelah and the Bee'' is so warm and well-meaning that you may find yourself wanting to like it more than you really do."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2006/04/28/spelling-error/ |title=Spelling Error |last=Smith |first=Kyle |date=April 28, 2006 |work=New York Post |publisher=[[News Corp]] |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7vh9Eb?url=http://nypost.com/2006/04/28/spelling-error/ |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
In spite of criticism, cast members' performances were usually well received – in particular, Palmer's portrayal of Akeelah. Ebert said, "The movie depends on her, and she deserves its trust."<ref name=ebert/> Hornaday opined that "Palmer's Akeelah is that cinematic ''[[wikt:rara avis|rara avis]]'', the kid who is cute without being too cute, sympathetic without being cloying, and believable without being tiresome."<ref name=wpost/> ''Evening Chronicle'' stated Palmer does it "with effortless grace" and that she "carries the film and doesn't strike a single wrong emotional note."<ref name=chronicle/> Fuchs felt that most of the film's strengths "have to do with Palmer's winning performance."<ref name=fuchs/> Ingman declared Atchison's "ensemble is wonderful, and his star, Palmer, is a fantastically assured young actress who conveys Akeelah's maelstrom of 11-year-old feelings with no apparent effort."<ref name=austinc/> Turan complimented how Fishburne and Bassett's "presence and ability give this film a welcome integrity."<ref name=turan/> Mohan stated, "Although Fishburne and Bassett can do these roles in their sleep, the kids are actually quite engaging."<ref name=oregon/> Tourmakine felt there were "fine performances all around" and that Fishburne and Bassett "lend fine support in utterly believable roles".<ref name=filmj/>
====Racial issues==== Chang called Dylan's father "a stiff Asian stereotype",<ref name=chang/> while Mohan of ''The Oregonian'' found it contradictory for an anti-racist film to contain such depiction.<ref name=oregon/> [[Peter Bradshaw]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' even claimed that the line "If you can barely beat a little black girl" (spoken by Dylan's father) signifies that Atchison "thinks it's all right to bring in racism by making the Asians the racists."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2006/aug/18/drama.family |title=Akeelah and the Bee |author=Bradshaw, Peter |work=The Guardian |date=August 18, 2006 |accessdate=June 21, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Qv7Z4BoP?url=http://www.theguardian.com/film/2006/aug/18/drama.family |archivedate=July 8, 2014 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> ''[[Metro Silicon Valley]]''{{'}}s Richard von Busack commented that "[s]tepping around black stereotypes, the film squishes its two left feet right in the mire of Asian stereotyping."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metroactive.com/metro/04.26.06/akeelah-0617.html |title=Casting a Spell |author=von Busack, Richard |date=April 26, 2006 |work=Metro Silicon Valley |publisher=[[Metro Newspapers]] |accessdate=August 1, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aT67Wcg7?url=http://www.metroactive.com/metro/04.26.06/akeelah-0617.html |archivedate=August 1, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Beth Accomando of [[KPBS (TV)|KPBS]] also criticized Dylan and his father's portrayal as "painful cliches",<ref name=kpbs/> while Schager of ''Slant Magazine'' found it not authentic, even likening Dylan's father to [[Mao Zedong]].<ref name=slant/>
Scholars Charise Pimentel and Cathleen Sawyer from the [[Texas State University]] published an article titled "''Akeelah and the Bee'': Inspirational Story of African-American Intellect and Triumph or Racist Rhetoric Served Up On Another Platter?" on the May 2011 issue of journal ''Multicultural Perspectives''.{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=100}} On a [[critical discourse analysis]], the authors argue that despite appearing to be an "inoccent enough" film, it has major approaches that make it racist.{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=100}} First, it implies that African-Americans needs to be rescued by others;{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=100}} second, depicts African-Americans community as "marked by homelessness, poverty, criminality, unemployment, and remnants of gang activity";{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=101}} third, indicates that black people usually only achieve success through sports by "linking the very essence of Akeelah's phenomenal ability to spell to her rhythmic abilities";{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=103}} and shows that African-Americans only can succeed outside their communities, "far from the oppressive clutches of their own."{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=104}}
Linder, on her September 2011 paper "Spelling Out Racial Difference: Moving Beyond the Inspirational Discourses in ''Akeelah and the Bee''", also criticizes it saying it "acts as a platform for a racial melodrama through which ideals of whiteness are reinforced and strengthened."{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=19}} Using [[Linda Williams (film scholar)|Linda Williams]]' categories of what constitutes a racial [[melodrama]], Linder argues that it is described as an "inspirational" film because of "[its] portrayal of Akeelah's victimization by the black community that surrounds her" and of redemption only achieved "through the idealized discourse of young people's educational success as defined by dominant (white) culture."{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=22}} Linder said characters "are mostly represented as having 'no interest in escape' from societal oppressions and limitations" and that "there is no sign throughout the film of any kind of lasting change for Akeelah's school or her young peers."{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=30}}
Linder affirms that it creates a dichotomy between "success (whiteness) versus failure (blackness)."{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=30}} Pimentel and Sawyer, as well as Linder, identify Larabee as the one who makes this separation clear when he manifests his disregard of [[African American Vernacular English]].{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=26}}{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=101}} The co-authors wrote that Larabee implies that "legitimate forms of intelligence can only be achieved through a Eurocentric perspective, thus advancing the message that Akeelah must be rescued from her African-American ways of knowing, in order to be considered intellectual."{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=101}} Another contraposition commented by scholars was "between the supportive Dr. Larabee and Akeelah's skeptical mother."{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=28}} Pimental and Sawyer said she is portrayed as "an African-American obstructionist",{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=103-104}} while scholar Gloria Ladson‐Billings asserted she represents the stereotype of "ignorant Black woman".{{sfn|Ladson‐Billings|2009|p=93}} Although Fuchs said the film was able to avoid the "[[white savior narrative in film|white authority figure saves the underclass child]]" plotline by introducing Larabee,<ref name=fuchs/> Ladson‐Billings, Linder, and Pimentel and Sawyer opined that it did not.{{sfn|Pimentel|Sawyer|2011|p=103-104}}{{sfn|Ladson‐Billings|2009|p=93}} After all, Larabee, as Linder described, is "a non-threatening black man who has assimilated to white culture and who can be depended on to help assimilate others".{{sfn|Linder|2011|p=30}}
===Accolades=== The film was nominated for six [[Black Reel Awards]], winning only Best Actress for Palmer.<ref name=bra/><ref name=bra2/> Out of five [[NAACP Image Award]]s nominations, ''Akeelah and the Bee'' won Outstanding Actress in a Motion Picture and Outstanding Writing in a Feature Film/Television Movie - Comedy or Drama.<ref name=image/><ref name=image2/> At the [[Black Movie Awards]], it won the five awards it was nominated for.<ref name=bma/> The same happened during the [[Young Artist Awards]] where it was nominated for two categories and won two awards,<ref name=young/> and at the [[CAMIE Awards]] where it was nominated for and won an award.<ref name=camie/> The film was also nominated for but did not win any award from the [[BET Awards]],<ref name=bet/><ref name=bet2/> [[Broadcast Film Critics Association Awards]],<ref name=bfca/> [[Chicago Film Critics]],<ref name=cfc/><ref name=cfc2/> and [[Satellite Awards]].<ref name=sat/><ref name=sat2/> [[National Board of Review]] elected it among the best ten independent films produced in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/board-review-votes-iwo-jima-145666 |title=Board of Review votes 'Iwo Jima' best picture |author=Goldstein, Gregg |work=The Hollywood Reporter |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |accessdate=July 20, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6a9gh2DR4?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/board-review-votes-iwo-jima-145666 |archivedate=July 20, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Additionally, two film critics, Chris Kaltenbach of ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'' and Carrie Rickey of ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'', added the film on their list of the ten best films of the year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2006-12-29/features/0612290186_1_controversial-films-lenfant-film-ends |title=Chris Kaltenbach's Favorite Films |author=Kaltenbach, Chris |date=December 29, 2006 |work=The Baltimore Sun |publisher=Tribune Publishing |accessdate=May 23, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YkHBIS9l?url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2006-12-29/features/0612290186_1_controversial-films-lenfant-film-ends |archivedate=May 23, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.philly.com/2006-12-31/entertainment/25398368_1_great-performances-akeelah-actress-categories |title=2006 The Year on Screen - As performers reclaimed the movies, give them an A for acting |author=Rickey, Carrie |date=December 31, 2006 |work=The Philadelphia Inquirer |publisher=[[Philadelphia Media Network]] |accessdate=May 23, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6YkHECiOq?url=http://articles.philly.com/2006-12-31/entertainment/25398368_1_great-performances-akeelah-actress-categories |archivedate=May 23, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> ''[[St. Petersburg Times]]''{{'}}s Steve Persall elected it the best family film of 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/12/29/Floridian/For_fans__a_happy_end.shtml |title=For fans, a happy ending after all |author=Persall, Steve |date=December 29, 2006 |work=St. Petersburg Times |publisher=[[Times Publishing Company]] |accessdate=July 26, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6aJuKWqT6?url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/12/29/Floridian/For_fans__a_happy_end.shtml |archivedate=July 26, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>

revision.text:
'''AngloMockBa''' is an international/British-Russian festival of arts, fashion, film, media, music, ideas and literature to be held in [[Moscow]] from 1–3 May.
It is understood to be the second edition of the [[Jewel of Russia Festival]]. According to the festival website, AngloMockBa is sponsored by [[TIME]], [[Swissotel]] and [[BMI (airline)|BMI]]. Guests include leading British and Russian cultural and media personalities such as [[Michael Nyman]], [[Martha Fiennes]], [[Gavin Turk]], [[Michael Craig-Martin]], [[Stephen Jones (milliner)|Stephen Jones]], [[Andrei Konchalovsky]], Masha Tsigal, [[William Orbit]], [[Henry Holland (fashion designer)|Henry Holland]], [[Dylan Jones]] and [[Stephen Frears]].
The festival is directed by [[Liberatum]] and Red Square PR.
==External links== *[http://www.liberatum.org.uk AngloMockBa Liberatum Website] *[http://www.redsquarepr.com AngloMockBa Red Square PR Website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110708023243/http://www.anglomockba.blogspot.com/ AngloMockBa Official Blog]
{{Russia-stub}} {{festival-stub}}

The '''Architecture Firm Award''' is the highest honor that [[American_Institute_of_Architects | The American Institute of Architects]] can bestow on an architecture firm for consistently producing distinguished architecture.
Prior recipients of the AIA Architecture Firm Award include:<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.aia.org/practicing/awards/AIAS075259|publisher=AIA|title=Architecture Firm Award recipients|accessdate=2010-11-23}}</ref>
*[[2018 in architecture|2018]]: Snow Kreilich Architects *[[2017 in architecture|2017]]: Leddy Maytum Stacy Architects *[[2016 in architecture|2016]]: LMN Architects *[[2015 in architecture|2015]]: [[Steven Ehrlich|Ehrlich Architects]]<ref>{{cite news |last=Madsen |first=Deane |url=http://www.architectmagazine.com/awards/2015-aia-honor-awards--architecture-firm-award_o.aspx |title=Ehrlich Architects Wins the 2015 Architecture Firm Award |work=[[Architect magazine|Architect]] |date=December 10, 2014 |accessdate=2015-01-13 }}</ref> *[[2014 in architecture|2014]]: [[Eskew+Dumez+Ripple]] *[[2013 in architecture|2013]]: [[Tod Williams Billie Tsien Architects]] *[[2012 in architecture|2012]]: [[VJAA]] *[[2011 in architecture|2011]]: [[BNIM|BNIM Architects]]<ref>{{cite news|title=BNIM Architects Wins 2011 AIA Architecture Firm Award |work= |publisher=interiordesign |date=January 28, 2011 |url=http://designwire.interiordesign.net/events/awards-honors/3358/bnim-architects-wins-2011-aia-architecture-firm-award |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110403020056/http://designwire.interiordesign.net/events/awards-honors/3358/bnim-architects-wins-2011-aia-architecture-firm-award |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 3, 2011 |accessdate=13 October 2011 }}</ref> *[[2010 in architecture|2010]]: [[Pugh + Scarpa]] *[[2009 in architecture|2009]]: [[Olson Sundberg Kundig Allen Architects]] *[[2008 in architecture|2008]]: [[KieranTimberlake Associates]], LLP *2007: [[Leers Weinzapfel Associates]] Architects, Inc. *2006: [[Moore Ruble Yudell Architects and Planners]] *2005: [[Murphy/Jahn]] *2004: revision.text:
{{For|"Works Cited" lists|Citation}} {{Redirect|Bibliology|the theological study of the nature of the Bible|Biblical theology}} [[Image:Library-shelves-bibliographies-Graz.jpg|thumb|250px|Bibliographies at the [[University Library of Graz]]]] '''Bibliography''' (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] βιβλίον ''biblion'', "book" and -γραφία ''-graphia'', "writing"), as a discipline, is traditionally the academic study of [[book]]s as physical, cultural objects; in this sense, it is also known as '''bibliology'''<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia=The Oxford English Dictionary |title=bibliology |edition=2nd |year=1989}}</ref> (from Greek {{lang|grc|-λογία}}, ''[[-logy|-logia]]''). Carter and Barker (2010) describe bibliography as a twofold scholarly discipline—the organized listing of books (enumerative bibliography) and the systematic description of books as objects (descriptive bibliography).
== Etymology == The word ''bibliographia'' (βιβλιογραφία) was used by Greek writers in the first three centuries AD to mean the copying of books by hand. In the 12th century, the word started being used for "the intellectual activity of composing books". The 17th century then saw the emergence of the modern meaning, that of description of books.<ref>Blum, Rudolf. ''Bibliographia, an inquiry into its definition and designations''. Translated by Mathilde V. Rovelstad. Chicago, Ill.: American Library Association; Folkestone, Kent, England: Dawson, 1980. p. 12. {{ISBN|0-8389-0146-8}}.</ref> Currently, the field of bibliography has expanded to include studies that consider the book as a material object.<ref>Studies in Bibliography. http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/bsuva/sb/</ref> Bibliography in its systematic pursuit of understanding the past and the present through written and printed documents describes a way and means of extracting information from this material. Bibliographers are interested in comparing versions of texts to each other rather than in interpreting their meaning or assessing their significance.<ref>O'Hagan Hardy, M. (2017). Bibliographic enterprise and the digital age: Charles Evans and the making of early American literature. ''American Literary History, 29''(2), 331-351.</ref>
== Field of study == Bibliography is a specialized aspect of [[library science]] (or [[library and information science]], LIS) and [[documentation science]]. It was established by a [[Belgian]], named [[Paul Otlet]] (1868-1944), who was the founder of the field of documentation, as a branch of the information sciences, who wrote about "the science of bibliography."<ref>Otlet, P. (1903). ''Les sciences bibliographiques et la documentation''. Bruxelles, Institut international de bibliographie.</ref><ref>Otlet, P. (1903). "The science of bibliography and documentation"2. In Rayward, W.B. (trans. and ed.), (1990), ''International organisation and dissemination of knowledge: Selected essays of Paul Otlet''. FID, Amsterdam: Elsevier. </ref> However, there have recently been voices claiming that "the bibliographical paradigm" is obsolete, and it is not today common in LIS. A defense of the bibliographical paradigm was provided by Hjørland (2007).<ref>Hjørland, B. (2007). "Arguments for 'the bibliographical paradigm'. Some thoughts inspired by the new English edition of the UDC", Information Research, 12(4) paper colis06. [Available at http://InformationR.net/ir/12-4/colis06.html]</ref> The quantitative study of bibliographies is known as [[bibliometrics]], which is today an influential subfield in LIS. <ref>{{cite book|title=Bibliography and the Sociology of Texts|last=McKenzie|first=D. F.|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1999|location=Cambridge}}</ref> <ref>Gow, A. S. F. ''A. E. Housman: A Sketch.'' Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011. Print</ref>
== Branches == Carter and Barker (2010) describe bibliography as a twofold scholarly discipline—the organized listing of books (enumerative bibliography) and the systematic description of books as physical objects (descriptive bibliography). These two distinct concepts and practices have separate rationales and serve differing purposes. Innovators and originators in the field include [[W. W. Greg]], [[Fredson Bowers]], [[Philip Gaskell]], [[G. Thomas Tanselle]].
Bowers (1949) refers to enumerative bibliography as a procedure that identifies books in “specific collections or libraries,” in a specific discipline, by an author, printer, or period of production (3). He refers to descriptive bibliography as the systematic description of a book as a material or physical artifact. Analytical bibliography, the cornerstone of descriptive bibliography, investigates the printing and all physical features of a book that yield evidence establishing a book's history and transmission (Feather 10). It is the preliminary phase of bibliographic description and provides the vocabulary, principles and techniques of analysis that descriptive bibliographers apply and on which they base their descriptive practice.
Descriptive bibliographers follow specific conventions and associated classification in their description. Titles and title pages are transcribed in a quasi-facsimile style and representation. Illustration, typeface, binding, paper, and all physical elements related to identifying a book follow formulaic conventions, as Bowers established in his foundational opus, ''The Principles of Bibliographic Description''. The thought expressed in this book expands substantively on W. W. Greg's groundbreaking theory that argued for the adoption of formal bibliographic principles (Greg 29). Fundamentally, analytical bibliography is concerned with objective, physical analysis and history of a book while descriptive bibliography employs all data that analytical bibliography furnishes and then codifies it with a view to identifying the ideal copy or form of a book that most nearly represents the printer's initial conception and intention in printing.
In addition to viewing bibliographic study as being composed of four interdependent approaches (enumerative, descriptive, analytical, and textual), Bowers notes two further subcategories of research, namely historical bibliography and aesthetic bibliography.<ref>Fredson Bowers, "Four Faces of Bibliography" Papers of the Bibliographical Society of Canada 10 (1971):33-4.</ref> Both historical bibliography, which involves the investigation of printing practices, tools, and related documents, and aesthetic bibliography, which examines the art of designing type and books, are often employed by analytical bibliographers.
D. F. McKenzie extended previous notions of bibliography as set forth by W. W. Greg, Bowers, Gaskell and Tanselle. He describes the nature of bibliography as "the discipline that studies texts as recorded forms, and the processes of their transmission, including their production and reception" (1999 12). This concept broadens the scope of bibliography to include "non-book texts" and an accounting for their material form and structure, as well as textual variations, technical and production processes that bring sociocultural context and effects into play. McKenzie's perspective contextualizes textual objects or artifacts with sociological and technical factors that have an effect on production, transmission and, ultimately, ideal copy (2002 14). Bibliography, generally, concerns the material conditions of books [as well as other texts] how they are designed, edited, printed, circulated, reprinted, collected.<ref>Philip Gaskell, ''A New Introduction to Bibliography'' (2000).</ref>
Bibliographic works differ in the amount of detail depending on the purpose and can generally be divided into two categories: enumerative bibliography (also called compilative, reference or systematic), which results in an overview of [[publication]]s in a particular category and analytical or critical bibliography, which studies the production of books.<ref>Belanger, Terry. "[http://www.bibsocamer.org/bibdef.htm Descriptive Bibliography]" Bibliographical Society of America, 2003. Excerpted from Jean Peters, ed., ''Book Collecting: A Modern Guide'' (New York and London: R. R. Bowker, 1977), 97–101.</ref><ref>Harris, Neil. [http://ihl.enssib.fr/siteihl.php?page=56 ''Analytical bibliography: an alternative prospectus''. Chapter 1. Definitions of bibliography, and in particular of the variety called analytical] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012140139/http://ihl.enssib.fr/siteihl.php?page=56 |date=2007-10-12 }}. Institut d'histoire du livre, 2004.</ref> In earlier times, bibliography mostly focused on books. Now, both categories of bibliography cover works in other media including audio recordings, motion pictures and videos, graphic objects, databases, CD-ROMs<ref>Harmon, Robert B. ''Elements of bibliography: a simplified approach''. Rev. ed. Metuchen, N.J.: Scarecrow Press, 1989. p. 4. {{ISBN|0-8108-2218-0}}.</ref> and websites.
=== Enumerative bibliography === [[File:Pn-samara-n-a-2000-11.jpg|thumb|Bibliographer workplace in Russia]] An enumerative bibliography is a systematic list of books and other works such as [[academic journal|journal]] [[article (publishing)|article]]s. Bibliographies range from "works [[citation|cited]]" lists at the end of books and articles, to complete and independent publications. A notable example of a complete, independent publication is Gow's, ''A. E. Housman: A Sketch, Together with a List of His Classical Papers'' (1936). As separate works, they may be in bound volumes such as those shown on the right, or computerized [[bibliographic database]]s. A [[library catalog]], while not referred to as a "bibliography," is bibliographic in nature. Bibliographical works are almost always considered to be [[tertiary source]]s.
Enumerative bibliographies are based on a unifying principle such as creator, subject, date, topic or other characteristic. An entry in an enumerative bibliography provides the core elements of a text resource including a title, the creator(s), publication date and place of publication. Belanger (1977) distinguishes an enumerative bibliography from other bibliographic forms such as descriptive bibliography, analytical bibliography or textual bibliography in that its function is to record and list, rather than describe a source in detail or with any reference to the source's physical nature, materiality or textual transmission. The enumerative list may be comprehensive or selective. One noted example would be Tanselle's bibliography that exhaustively enumerates topics and sources related to all forms of bibliography. A more common and particular instance of an enumerative bibliography relates to specific sources used or considered in preparing a scholarly paper or academic term paper.
Citation styles vary.
An entry for a book in a bibliography usually contains the following elements: * creator(s) * title * place of publication * publisher or printer * date of publication
An entry for a journal or periodical article usually contains: * creator(s) * article title * journal title * volume * pages * date of publication
A bibliography may be arranged by author, topic, or some other scheme. [[Annotated bibliography|Annotated bibliographies]] give descriptions about how each source is useful to an author in constructing a paper or argument. These descriptions, usually a few sentences long, provide a summary of the source and describe its relevance. [[Reference management software]] may be used to keep track of references and generate bibliographies as required.
Bibliographies differ from [[library catalog]]s by including only relevant items rather than all items present in a particular library. However, the catalogs of some [[national library|national libraries]] effectively serve as {{illm|National bibliography|de|Nationalbibliografie|lt=national bibliographies}}, as the national libraries own almost all their countries' publications.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.ifla.org/node/2216 |work= Ifla.org |title= National Bibliographic Register |accessdate= 1 December 2017 |publisher=[[International Federation of Library Associations and Institutions]] |location=The Hague }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bl.uk/reshelp/findhelprestype/refworks/natbib/bibprint.html |work= Help for researchers |title=National bibliographies and books in print |publisher=British Library |accessdate= 1 December 2017 }}</ref>
=== Descriptive bibliography === Fredson Bowers described and formulated a standardized practice of descriptive bibliography in his ''Principles of Bibliographical Description'' (1949). Scholars to this day treat Bowers' scholarly guide as authoritative. In this classic text, Bowers describes the basic function of bibliography as, "[providing] sufficient data so that a reader may identify the book described, understand the printing, and recognize the precise contents" (124).
==== Descriptive bibliographies as scholarly product ==== Descriptive bibliographies as a scholarly product usually include information on the following aspect of a given book as a material object: *Format and Collation/Pagination Statement – a conventional, symbolic formula that describes the book block in terms of sheets, folds, quires, signatures, and pages :::According to Bowers (193), the format of a book is usually abbreviated in the collation formula: ::::Broadsheet: I° or b.s. or bs. ::::Folio: 2° or fol. ::::Quarto: 4° or 4to or Q° or Q ::::Octavo: 8° or 8vo ::::Duodecimo: 12° or 12mo ::::Sexto-decimo: 16° or 16mo ::::Tricesimo-secundo: 32° or 32mo ::::Sexagesimo-quarto: 64° or 64mo :::The collation, which follows the format, is the statement of the order and size of the gatherings. ::::For example, a quarto that consists of the signed gatherings: :::::2 leaves signed A, 4 leaves signed B, 4 leaves signed C, and 2 leaves signed D ::::would be represented in the collation formula: :::::4°: A<sup>2</sup>B-C<sup>4</sup>D<sup>2</sup> *Binding – a description of the binding techniques (generally for books printed after 1800) *Title Page Transcription – a transcription of the title page, including rule lines and ornaments *Contents – a listing of the contents (by section) in the book *Paper – a description of the physical properties of the paper, including production process, an account of chain-line measurements, and a description of watermarks (if present) *Illustrations – a description of the illustrations found in the book, including printing process (e.g. woodblock, intaglio, etc.), measurements, and locations in the text *Presswork – miscellaneous details gleaned from the text about its production *Copies Examined – an enumeration of the copies examined, including those copies' location (i.e. belonging to which library or collector)
=== Analytical bibliography === This branch of the bibliographic discipline examines the material features of a textual artifact – such as type, ink, paper, imposition, format, impressions and states of a book – to essentially recreate the conditions of its production. Analytical bibliography often uses collateral evidence – such as general printing practices, trends in format, responses and non-responses to design, etc. – to scrutinize the historical conventions and influences underlying the physical appearance of a text. The bibliographer utilizes knowledge gained from the investigation of physical evidence in the form of a descriptive bibliography or textual bibliography.<ref name="New Encyclopædia Britannica: Macropaedia">{{cite book|last=Bowers|first=Fredson|title=Bibliography|year=1974|edition=2nd|pages=978–981}}</ref> Descriptive bibliography is the close examination and cataloging of a text as a physical object, recording its size, format, [[bookbinding|binding]], and so on, while textual bibliography (or textual criticism) identifies variations – and the aetiology of variations – in a text with a view to determining "the establishment of the most correct form of [a] text (Bowers 498[1]).
== Bibliographers == [[File:Paul Otlet à son bureau.jpg|thumb|[[Paul Otlet]], to work in an office built at his home following the closure of the [[Mundaneum|Palais Mondial]] in June 1937]] A ''bibliographer'' is a person who describes and lists books and other publications, with particular attention to such characteristics as authorship, publication date, edition, typography, etc. A person who limits such efforts to a specific field or discipline is a subject bibliographer."<ref>{{cite web|last=Reitz|first= Joan M. |year=2010|url= http://www.abc-clio.com/ODLIS/odlis_b.aspx |title=Online Dictionary for Library and Information Science|publisher=abc-clio.com}}</ref>
A bibliographer, in the technical meaning of the word, is anyone who writes about books. But the accepted meaning since at least the 18th century is a person who attempts a comprehensive account—sometimes just a list, sometimes a fuller reckoning—of the books written on a particular subject. In the present, bibliography is no longer a career, generally speaking; bibliographies tend to be written on highly specific subjects and by specialists in the field.
The term ''bibliographer'' is sometimes—in particular subject bibliographer—today used about certain roles performed in libraries<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mla.org/bib_bibliographers |title=MLA Field Bibliographers |publisher=mla.org |date= |accessdate=2013-10-08}}</ref> and [[bibliographic database]]s.
== Non-book material == Systematic lists of media other than books can be referred to with terms formed analogously to ''bibliography'': * [[Discography]] – recorded music * [[Filmography]] – films * [[Webography]] (or webliography) – websites (the first use of the word "webliography" recorded in the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' dates from June 1995)
Arachniography is a term coined by [[NASA]] research historian Andrew J. Butrica, which means a reference list of [[URL]]s about a particular subject. It is equivalent to a bibliography in a book. The name derives from ''[[arachne]]'' in reference to a spider and its web.<ref name=atlantic2007>{{cite book | author=Staff | page=28 | title=Encyclopedia Of Information Technology | publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Distributors | year=2007 | isbn=81-269-0752-5 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=McKenzie|first=D. F.|title=Making Meaning: Printers of the Mind and Other Essays|year=2002|publisher=University of Massachusetts Press|location=Amherst}}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|books}} <!-- * [[Bibliology]] --> * [[Bibliographic index]] * [[Citation]] * [[Citation creator]] * [[History of the book]] * [[Ibid.]] / [[Op cit]] * [[Indexing and abstracting service]] * [[ISO 690]], an international standard for bibliographic referencing * [[List of bibliographies]] (in Wikipedia) * [[Metabibliography]] (bibliography of bibliographies) * [[Reference table]] * [[Legal bibliography]] * [[Style guide]] * [[Textual scholarship]]
== References == {{Reflist|35em}}
== Further reading == * Blum, Rudolf. (1980) ''Bibliographia. An Inquiry in Its Definition and Designations'', Dawson, American Library Association. * Bowers, Fredson. (1995) ''Principles of Bibliographical Description'', Oak Knoll Press. * Duncan, Paul Shaner. (1973) ''How to Catalog a Rare Book'', 2nd ed., rev., American Library Association. * {{cite book |chapter=Bibliography |url=http://www.ilab.org/eng/documentation/29-abc_for_book_collectors.html |title=ABC for Book Collectors |edition= 8th |publisher= Oak Knoll Press and British Library |year= 2004 |author1=[[John Carter (author)|John Carter]] |author2=Nicolas Barker |isbn=1-58456-112-2 }} {{free access}} * Gaskell, Philip. (2000) ''A New Introduction to Bibliography'', Oak Knoll Press. * McKerrow, R. B. (1927) ''An Introduction to Bibliography for Literary Students'', Oxford: Clarendon Press * Schneider, Georg. (1934) ''Theory and History of Bibliography'', New York: Scarecrow Press. * National Library of Canada, Committee on Bibliography and Information Services for the Social Sciences and Humanities, ''Guidelines for the Compilation of a Bibliography'' (National Library of Canada, 1987). ''N.B''.: This is a brief guide to accurately practical bibliography, not a study concerning more precise and systematic bibliography. * {{cite book|author=British Museum. Department of Printed Books |title=Hand List of Bibliographies, Classified Catalogues, and Indexes Placed in the Reading Room of the British Museum for Reference|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r-0QAAAAIAAJ|year=1881|publisher=Printed by William Clowes and Sons |location=London }} *Robinson, A. M. Lewin (1966) ''Systematic Bibliography''; rev. ed. London: Clive Bingley
== External links == {{Wiktionary}} {{EB1911 poster|Bibliography and Bibliology}} {{Wikisource|Portal:Bibliography}} {{Wikiversity}} * [http://oxfordbibliographiesonline.com/ Oxford Bibliographies Online], in-depth annotated bibliographies by scholars in selected fields * [http://rarebookschool.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/syl-B-complete.090302.pdf Introduction to Bibliography], a comprehensive syllabus by G. Thomas Tanselle * [http://www.bibsocamer.org/ The Bibliographical Society of America], a resource for information about current work in the field of bibliography * [http://etext.lib.virginia.edu/bsuva/sb/ Studies in Bibliography], the journal of the [[Bibliographical Society of the University of Virginia]] * [http://www.unizar.es/departamentos/filologia_inglesa/garciala/bibliography.html A Bibliography of Literary Theory, Criticism, and Philology], (University of Zaragoza) includes thousands of listings on literary, philological and other subjects

{{Other uses|DC Universe (disambiguation)}} {{Redirect|DC Animated|the feature films series also produced by Warner Bros. Animation|DC Universe Animated Original Movies}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} [[File:DCAU.jpg|thumb|270px|An image of several DCAU heroes from the ''[[Justice League Unlimited]]'' episode "Dark Heart"]] The '''DC Animated Universe''' ('''DCAU'''; also referred to as the '''Timmverse''' by fans) is the [[shared universe]] centered on a group of [[Animated series|animated television series]] based on [[DC Comics]], produced by [[Warner Bros. Animation]] from the early 1990s to mid-2000s; beginning with ''[[Batman: The Animated Series]]'' in 1992, and ending with ''[[Justice League Unlimited]]'' in 2006.{{cite news|title= A History of Batman on TV|work= IGN|url= http://uk.tv.ign.com/articles/891/891807p7.html|accessdate=August 15, 2010}}[http://comics.ign.com/articles/758/758931p3.html "The Greatest Comic Book Cartoons of All Time"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120529093939/http://comics.ign.com/articles/758/758931p3.html |date=May 29, 2012 }}. IGN. January 26, 2007. Retrieved May 31, 2011. Some parts of the associated media franchise including [[direct-to-video]] feature films and [[Short film|shorts]], comic books, video games and other multimedia adaptations are also included in the continuity. == List of DCAU media == [[File:DCAU batsuits.jpg|thumb|220px|[[Batman]]'s various character designs from the DCAU; he has been the most-featured character in this animated continuity, due to being the star of the original TV series in the DCAU.]] While there have been several animated projects based upon DC Comics characters over the decades, what is commonly accepted as the DC animated universe consists of the stable of TV series and films that spin off from ''Batman: The Animated Series'' (1992–1995), the first TV show in this continuity. Two characters outside of the normal [[Batman]] canon, [[Zatanna]] and [[Jonah Hex]], appeared on the show, but the first series to indicate a shared continuity with other well-known characters was the subsequent show, ''[[Superman: The Animated Series]]'', in which the [[Superman|title character]] has encounters with heroes such as the [[Flash (comics)|Flash]] and the [[Green Lantern]]. Older shows such as ''[[Super Friends]]'' and newer shows such as ''[[The Batman (TV series)|The Batman]]'', ''[[Legion of Super Heroes (TV series)|Legion of Super Heroes]]'', ''[[Batman: The Brave and the Bold]]'', and ''[[Young Justice (TV series)|Young Justice]]'' are not part of this continuity. The direct-to-video [[DC Universe Animated Original Movies]], such as ''[[Superman: Doomsday]]'', ''[[Justice League: The New Frontier]]'' and ''[[Batman: Gotham Knight]]'', are also not considered part of the DCAU, despite utilizing similar character designs and several of them featuring much of the same voice cast as previous DCAU series. === TV series === The DC animated universe consists of these animated series (and their related films; see below): {| class="wikitable" |- ! Series ! Airdates ! Channel ! Connection |- | ''[[Batman: The Animated Series]]'' | September 5, 1992 – September 15, 1995 | [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] | '''Starting point for the universe'''
'''Soft introductions:'''
"Zatanna" (Zatanna)
"Showdown" (Jonah Hex) |- | ''[[Superman: The Animated Series]]'' | September 6, 1996 – February 12, 2000 | rowspan="5"|[[The WB Television Network|The WB]] | '''Crossovers with ''The New Batman Adventures'':'''
''World's Finest''
''Knight Time''
''The Demon Reborn''
'''Soft introductions:'''
''Speed Demons'' (The Flash)
''The Hand of Fate'' (Dr. Fate)
''Heavy Metal'' (Steel)
''In Brightest Day'' (The Green Lantern Corps)
''A Fish Story'' (Aquaman)
''The Main Man Parts 1 and 2'' (Lobo) |- | ''[[The New Batman Adventures]]'' | September 13, 1997 – January 16, 1999 | '''Sequel to ''Batman: The Animated Series'''''
'''Crossovers with ''Superman: The Animated Series'':'''
''Girl's Night Out''
'''Soft introductions:'''
''The Demon Within'' (Etrigan)
''Beware The Creeper'' (The Creeper) |- | ''[[Batman Beyond]]'' | January 10, 1999 – December 18, 2001 | '''Sequel to ''The New Batman Adventures'''''
'''Crossovers with The Zeta Project:'''
''Countdown''
'''Soft Introductions:'''
''Zeta'' (Infiltration Unit Zeta)
''The Call'' (The Justice League Unlimited) |- | ''[[Static Shock]]'' | September 23, 2000 – May 22, 2004 | '''Crossovers:'''
''The Big Leagues'' (The New Batman Adventures)
''Fallen Hero'' (Justice League)
''Future Shock'' (The New Batman Adventures/Batman Beyond)

''A League of Their Own'' (Justice League)
''Toys in the Hood'' (Superman: The Animated Series) |- | ''[[The Zeta Project]]'' | January 27, 2001 – August 17, 2002 | '''Spin-off of Batman Beyond'''
'''Crossovers with Batman Beyond:'''
''Shadows'' |- | ''[[Justice League (TV series)|Justice League]]'' | November 17, 2001 – May 29, 2004 | rowspan="2"|[[Cartoon Network]] | '''Sequel to ''Superman: The Animated Series'' and ''The New Batman Adventures''''' |- | ''[[Justice League Unlimited]]'' | July 31, 2004 – May 13, 2006 | '''Sequel to Justice League'''
'''Crossovers'''
''The Once And Future Thing'' (Static Shock/Batman Beyond)
''Epilogue'' (Batman Beyond) |} An animated series based on the ''[[Teen Titans]]'' comic books was planned for the DC animated universe during the mid-1990s, but was finally scrapped.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/WF/sections/backstage/abandoned/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-07-07 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160521063619/http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/WF/sections/backstage/abandoned/ |archivedate=May 21, 2016 |df=mdy }} Instead a ''Teen Titans'' series not related to the DC animated universe was released. Also, after the success of ''Batman: The Animated Series'' in the early 1990s, Fox approached producer [[Bruce Timm]] to create a spin-off series focusing on [[Catwoman]], but the project never materialized. === Feature-length films === The following animated feature films also are part of the DCAU continuity: *''[[Batman: Mask of the Phantasm]]'' (1993; theatrical release){{cite web|url= http://ca.ign.com/articles/2010/06/25/top-25-animated-movies-of-all-time| title=''Top 25 Animated Movies of All-Time''| publisher= [[IGN]]|accessdate=2012-10-10}}{{cite web |url= http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/batman_mask_of_the_phantasm/ |title=''Batman: Mask of the Phantasm''| work =[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher = [[Flixster]] |accessdate=2008-01-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080130003635/http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/batman_mask_of_the_phantasm/| archivedate= January 30, 2008 | deadurl= no}} *''[[Batman & Mr. Freeze: SubZero]]'' (1998; direct-to-video) *''[[Batman Beyond: Return of the Joker]]'' (2000; direct-to-video) *''[[Batman: Mystery of the Batwoman]]'' (2003; direct-to-video) Before the release of ''[[Batman Beyond: Return of the Joker]]'', a third animated feature based on ''[[Batman: The Animated Series]]'' was planned, entitled ''Batman: Arkham''. The film was supposed to be a follow-up for ''[[Batman & Mr. Freeze: SubZero]]'', and [[Boyd Kirkland]] was attached to write and direct; but the project was soon scrapped. A second ''[[Batman Beyond]]'' movie was planned for release but was finally scrapped due to the dark tones and controversies of ''[[Batman Beyond: Return of the Joker]]'' in 2001.{{cite web |url=http://jl.toonzone.net/episode50/episode50.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-01-02 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160516063839/http://jl.toonzone.net/episode50/episode50.htm |archivedate=May 16, 2016 |df=mdy }} Around 2003, during the production of ''[[Batman: Mystery of the Batwoman]]'', [[Warner Bros.]] approached Kirkland to write a [[Catwoman]] [[direct-to-video]] feature film as a tie-in with the [[Catwoman (film)|2004 live-action film]]. Although the script was written, the project was soon scrapped after the poor reception of the live-action film.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/WF/batman/btas/backstage/interviews/kirkland.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-11-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530010942/http://worldsfinestonline.com/WF/batman/btas/backstage/interviews/kirkland.php |archivedate=May 30, 2015 |df=mdy }} Also, a direct-to-video feature-length animated film entitled ''Justice League: Worlds Collide'' was planned to connect ''[[Justice League (animated series)|Justice League]]'' with its follow-up ''[[Justice League Unlimited]]'', but the production was finally cancelled in 2004, and the script was later rewritten for the animated film ''[[Justice League: Crisis on Two Earths]]'', that was not part of the DC animated universe.{{cite web|url=http://jl.toonzone.net/episodeC/episodeC.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-09-13 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303182731/http://jl.toonzone.net/episodeC/episodeC.htm |archivedate=March 3, 2016 |df=mdy }}{{cite web|url=http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/news.php?action%3Dfullnews%26id%3D222 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-08-31 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920221050/http://www.worldsfinestonline.com/news.php?action=fullnews&id=222 |archivedate=September 20, 2016 |df=mdy }} === Short films === *''The Dark Knight's First Night'' (1990) – A short film which acted as the developmental pilot for ''Batman: The Animated Series''. *''[[Chase Me]]'' (2003) – A short film with no dialogue based on ''The New Batman Adventures''. *''Batman Black & White: Two of a Kind'' (2008) - A motion comic adaptation of Bruce Timm's "Two-Face: Two of a Kind" *''Mad Love'' (2008) - A 3 part motion comic adaptation of Bruce Timm and Paul Dini's "Batman Adventures: Mad Love" *''Batman Beyond'' (2014) – A short film based on ''Batman Beyond'' created by [[Darwyn Cooke]] for Batman's 75th anniversary. The short features the original voice cast of the show, as well as cameos of robotic batmen from ''The New Batman Adventures'', ''[[The Batman (TV series)|The Batman]]'', ''[[Batman: The Brave and the Bold]]'', ''[[Beware the Batman]]'', ''[[The Dark Knight Returns]]'', [[Michael Keaton]]'s Batman, [[Adam West]]'s Batman, and the original comic book Batman from 1939. === Web cartoons === *''[[Gotham Girls]]'' (2000–2002) – A [[Adobe Flash|Macromedia Flash]] web cartoon series, this was downloadable from the WB website, and featured DCAU versions of characters voiced by their original actors. A DC Comics [[miniseries]] inspired by the web series was released in 2004. All three seasons of ''Gotham Girls'' were released on the ''[[Birds of Prey (TV series)|Birds of Prey]]'' DVD box set in 2008. *''[[Lobo (DC Comics)#Webseries|Lobo]]'' (2000) – A Flash cartoon series starring [[Lobo (DC Comics)|Lobo]], the galactic bounty hunter, the web-series is a spin-off of the ''[[Superman: The Animated Series|Superman]]'' episode "The Main Man." A wax statue with the same character design as Lobo in this series appeared in an episode of ''[[Gotham Girls]]'' and he also made a reappearance in the ''[[Justice League (TV series)|Justice League]]'' episode "Hereafter" briefly becoming a member of the Justice League. Both of these examples somewhat support that the webseries is part of the official DCAU, although this is still disputed. Unlike the other cartoons set in the DCAU, it has graphic violence, sexual content and strong profanity. === Comic books === {{Main article|DC animated universe (comics)}} Many of the DCAU productions have also had [[comic book]]s created based on the characters of the various series, though their canonicity is disputable. These are: ''The Adventures of Batman and Robin'' (SEGA CD/Mega CD version), ''Superman'', ''Batman Vengeance'', ''Superman: Shadow of Apokolips'', and ''Batman: Rise of Sin Tzu''.
