{{Infobox book | name = The Minds of Billy Milligan | image = File:TheMindsOfBillyMilligan.jpg | caption = 1981 edition cover | author = [[Daniel Keyes]] | country = United States | genre = [[Biography]] | publisher = [[Random House]] (1981)
[[Bantam Books]] (1982, 1995) | release_date = October 1981 | media_type = Print (hardcover & paperback) | pages = 374 (1981)
426 (1982,1995) | isbn = 0-3945-1943-4 | oclc = 7574826 }} '''''The Minds of Billy Milligan''''' is a [[non-fiction novel]] portraying [[Billy Milligan]], the first person in U.S. history acquitted of a major crime by pleading [[Dissociative identity disorder|multiple-personality disorder]].{{cite web |title=30 years later, multiple-personality case still fascinates |url=http://www.columbusdispatch.com/live/content/local_news/stories/2007/10/28/BILLY.ART_ART_10-28-07_A1_EV89AGB.html?sid=101 |website=The Columbus Dispatch |accessdate=2015-10-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120731110636/http://www.columbusdispatch.com/live/content/local_news/stories/2007/10/28/BILLY.ART_ART_10-28-07_A1_EV89AGB.html?sid=101 |archivedate=2012-07-31 |df= }} The novel was originally published in 1981, written by [[Hugo Award]] winning author [[Daniel Keyes]], who received a bachelor's degree in psychology from [[Brooklyn College]] in 1950.{{cite book |title=The Play of Daniel Keyes' Flowers for Algernon |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pIs9Em38dAoC |publisher=Heinemann |date=1993-01-01 |isbn=978-0-435-23293-1 |first=Bert |last=Coules |first2=Daniel |last2=Keyes}} The sequel entitled ''[[The Milligan Wars]]'',{{cite book |title=ビリー・ミリガンと23の棺 = The milligan wars |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/biri-mirigan-to-23-no-kan-the-milligan-wars/oclc/31096667?referer=di&ht=edition |publisher=早川書房 |date=1994-01-01 |location=東京 |isbn=4-15-207863-4 |language=Japanese |first=Daniel |last=Keyes}} was later published in Japan in 1994. According to the author, its release in the United States is tied to the release of the upcoming film adaptation entitled ''[[The Crowded Room]]''.{{cite web |title=Daniel Keyes FAQ |url=http://www.danielkeyesauthor.com/faq.html#bfaq |website=www.danielkeyesauthor.com |accessdate=2015-10-15}} == Awards == === Won === * 1986: [[Kurd-Laßwitz-Preis|Kurd Lasswitz Award]] for Best Book by a Foreign Author{{cite web |title=KLP 1986 Preisträger |url=http://www.kurd-lasswitz-preis.de/1981-1990/KLP_1986_Preistraeger.htm |website=[[kurd-lasswitz-preis]] |accessdate=2015-10-15}} * 1993: [[Seiun Award]] for Non-Fiction of the Year{{cite web |title=sfadb: Seiun Awards 1993 |url=http://www.sfadb.com/Seiun_Awards_1993 |website=www.sfadb.com |accessdate=2015-10-15}} === Nominated === * 1982: [[Edgar Award]] for Best Fact Crime{{cite web |title=Edgar Award Winners and Nominees Database |url=http://www.theedgars.com/edgarsDB/index.php |website=www.theedgars.com |accessdate=2015-10-15}} ==See also== *''[[Shelter (2010 film)|Shelter]]'', a 2010 film by [[Måns Mårlind]] and Björn Stein. *''[[Split (2016 American film)|Split]]'', a 2016 film by [[M. Night Shyamalan]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Daniel Keyes}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Minds of Billy Milligan, The}} [[Category:1981 books]] [[Category:English-language books]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:Non-fiction crime books]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:Non-fiction novels]] [[Category:Novels set in Ohio]] [[Category:American novels adapted into films]] [[Category:Random House books]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{other uses|Turn of the Screw (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox book | name = The Turn of the Screw | image = The-Turn-of-the-Screw-Collier's-1A.jpg | image_size = | caption = First page of the 12-part serialisation of
''The Turn of the Screw'' in ''[[Collier's]] Weekly''
(January 27 – April 16, 1898) | author = [[Henry James]] | country = United States{{sfn|Simon|2007|p=75}} | language = English | genre = {{hlist|[[Horror fiction|Horror]]|[[gothic fiction]]| [[ghost story]]}} | publisher = [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|The Macmillan Company]] {{small|(New York City)}}
[[Heinemann (publisher)|William Heinemann]] {{small|(London)}} | release_date = October 1898 | isbn = | congress = PS2116 .T8 1998 | oclc = 40043490 }} '''''The Turn of the Screw''''' is an 1898 [[horror fiction|horror]] novella by [[Henry James]] that first appeared in serial format in ''[[Collier's]] Weekly'' magazine (January 27 – April 16, 1898). In October 1898 it appeared in ''The Two Magics'', a book published by [[Macmillan Publishers (United States)|Macmillan]] in New York City and [[Heinemann (publisher)|Heinemann]] in London. Classified as both [[gothic fiction]] and a [[ghost story]], the novella focuses on a governess who, caring for two children at a remote estate, becomes convinced that the grounds are haunted. In the century following its publication, ''The Turn of the Screw'' became a cornerstone text of academics who subscribed to [[New Criticism]]. The novella has had differing interpretations, often mutually exclusive. Many critics have tried to determine the exact nature of the evil hinted at by the story. However, others have argued that the brilliance of the novella results from its ability to create an intimate sense of confusion and suspense within the reader. The novella has been adapted numerous times in radio drama, film, stage, and television, including a [[The Innocents (play)|1950 Broadway play]], and the 1961 film ''[[The Innocents (1961 film)|The Innocents]]''. == Plot == On Christmas Eve, an unnamed narrator listens to Douglas, a friend, read a manuscript written by a former [[governess]] whom Douglas claims to have known and who is now dead. The manuscript tells the story of how the young governess is hired by a man who has become responsible for his young nephew and niece after the deaths of their parents. He lives mainly in London but also has a country house, Bly. He is uninterested in raising the children. The boy, Miles, is attending a [[boarding school]], while his younger sister, Flora, is living at a summer country house in [[Essex]]. She is currently being cared for by Mrs. Grose, the housekeeper. Miles and Flora's uncle, the governess' new employer, gives her full charge of the children and explicitly states that she is not to bother him with communications of any sort. The governess travels to her new employer's country house and begins her duties. Miles soon returns from school for the summer just after a letter arrives from the headmaster stating that he has been expelled. Miles never speaks of the matter, and the governess is hesitant to raise the issue. She fears there is some horrible secret behind the expulsion but is too charmed by the adorable young boy to want to press the issue. Soon thereafter, around the grounds of the estate, the governess begins to see the figures of a man and woman whom she does not recognise. These figures come and go at will without ever being seen or challenged by other members of the household, and they seem to the governess to be supernatural. She learns from Mrs. Grose that the governess' predecessor, Miss Jessel, and another employee, Peter Quint, had had a sexual relationship. Before their deaths, Jessel and Quint spent much of their time with Flora and Miles, and this fact has grim significance for the current governess when she becomes convinced that the two children are secretly aware of the ghosts' presence. Later, without permission, Flora leaves the house while Miles is playing music for the governess. The governess notices Flora's absence and goes with Mrs. Grose in search of her. They find her in a [[folly]] on the shore of the lake, and the governess is convinced that Flora has been talking to the ghost of Miss Jessel. When the governess finally confronts Flora, the girl denies seeing Miss Jessel and demands never to see the governess again. At the governess' suggestion, Mrs. Grose takes Flora away to her uncle, leaving the governess with Miles, who that night at last talks to her about his expulsion; the ghost of Quint appears to the governess at the window. The governess shields Miles, who attempts to see the ghost. The governess tells Miles he is no longer controlled by the ghost and then finds that Miles has died in her arms, and the ghost has gone. == Major themes == Throughout his career James was attracted to the ghost story. However, he was not fond of literature's stereotypical ghosts. He preferred to create ghosts that were eerie extensions of everyday reality, "the strange and sinister embroidered on the very type of the normal and easy", as he put it in the ''[[New York Edition]]'' preface to his final ghost story, "[[The Jolly Corner]]". With ''The Turn of the Screw'', many critics have wondered if the "strange and sinister" were only in the governess's mind and not part of reality. The result has been a longstanding critical dispute about the reality of the ghosts and the sanity of the governess. Beyond the dispute, critics have closely examined James's narrative technique for the story. The framing introduction and subsequent [[first-person narrative]] by the governess have been studied by theorists of fiction interested in the power of fictional narratives to convince or even manipulate readers. The imagery of ''The Turn of the Screw'' is reminiscent of [[gothic fiction]]. The emphasis on old and mysterious buildings throughout the novella reinforces this motif. James also relates the amount of light present in various scenes to the strength of the supernatural or ghostly forces apparently at work. The governess refers directly to ''[[The Mysteries of Udolpho]]'' and indirectly to ''[[Jane Eyre]]'', evoking a comparison of the governess not only to the character of [[Jane Eyre (character)|Jane Eyre]], but also to the character of Bertha, the madwoman confined in Thornfield.{{cite book|author=Kaufmann, Professor Linda |title=Discourses of Desire|isbn= 0-8014-9510-5}} See this book for an argument that Bronte was actually the source of the tale, through Mary Sedgwick Benson. == Literary significance and criticism == [[Oliver Elton]] wrote in 1907 that "There is...doubt, raised and kept hanging, whether, after all, the two ghosts who can choose to which persons they will appear, are facts, or delusions of the young governess who tells the story."{{Cite book|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433074965207|title=Modern studies /|last=Elton|first=Oliver|date=1907|publisher=London :}} [[Edmund Wilson]] was another of the earlier proponents of the theory questioning the governess's sanity, positing [[sexual repression]] as a cause for her experiences.{{sfn|Slide|2013|p=103}} Wilson eventually recanted his opinion after considering the governess's point-by-point description of Quint. Then John Silver{{cite news|author=Smith, John|title=A Note on the [[Freudian]] Reading of 'The Turn of the Screw'|work=American Literature|year=1957}} pointed out hints in the story that the governess might have gained previous knowledge of Quint's appearance in non-supernatural ways. This induced Wilson to return to his original opinion that the governess was delusional and that the ghosts existed only in her imagination. [[William Veeder]] sees Miles's eventual death as induced by the governess. In a complex [[psychoanalytic]] reading, Veeder concludes that the governess expressed her repressed rage toward her father and toward the master of Bly on Miles.{{Cite journal|last=Veeder|first=William|date=August 1999|title=The Nurturance of the Gothic|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/3711133/nurturance-gothic|journal=Gothic Studies|volume=1|pages=47}} Other critics, however, have strongly defended the governess. They note that James's letters, his ''New York Edition'' preface, and his ''[[Notebooks of Henry James|Notebooks]]'' contain no definite evidence that ''The Turn of the Screw'' was intended as anything other than a straightforward ghost story, and James certainly wrote ghost stories that did not depend on the narrator's imagination. For example, "[[Owen Wingrave]]" includes a ghost that causes its title character's sudden death, although no one actually sees it. James's ''Notebooks'' entry indicates that he was inspired originally by a tale he heard from [[Edward White Benson]], the [[Archbishop of Canterbury]]. There are indications that the story James was told was about an incident in [[Hinton Ampner]], where in 1771 a woman named Mary Ricketts moved from her home after seeing the apparitions of a man and a woman, day and night, staring through the windows, bending over the beds, and making her feel her children were in danger.{{cite news|url= https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/9643165/How-we-all-came-to-love-a-good-ghost-story.html |title=Books: How we all came to love a good ghost story|work=The Daily Telegraph}}{{cite book|url=http://www.eso-garden.com/specials/the_gale_encyclopedia_of_the_unusual_and_unexplained_vol_3.pdf| title= The Gale Encyclopedia of the Unusual and Unexplained}} In a 2012 commentary in ''[[The New Yorker]]'', [[Brad Leithauser]] has given his own perspective on the different interpretations of James' novella:
All such attempts to 'solve' the book, however admiringly tendered, unwittingly work toward its diminution[; its] profoundest pleasure lies in the beautifully fussed over way in which James refuses to come down on either side... the book becomes a modest monument to the bold pursuit of ambiguity.{{cite news|work=The New Yorker|author=Leithauser, Brad|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/books/2012/10/ever-scarier-on-the-turn-of-the-screw.html|date=October 2012|title=Ever scarier on The Turn of the Screw}}
According to Leithauser, the reader is meant to entertain both the proposition that the governess is mad and the proposition that the ghosts really do exist, and consider the dreadful implications of each. Poet and literary critic [[Craig Raine]], in his essay "Sex in nineteenth-century literature", states quite categorically his belief that Victorian readers would have identified the two ghosts as child molesters.{{cite news|title=Sex in nineteenth-century literature |work= In Defence of T. S. Eliot|author=Raine, Craig }} == Publication history == ''The Turn of the Screw'' was first published in the magazine ''[[Collier's]] Weekly'', serialised in 12 instalments (27 January – 16 April 1898). The title illustration by [[John La Farge]] depicts the governess with her arm around Miles. Episode illustrations were by [[Eric Pape]].{{sfn|Orr|2009|p=23}} File:The-Turn-of-the-Screw-Collier's-1B.jpg|"The next night, by the corner of the hearth, in the best chair … Douglas began to read" File:The-Turn-of-the-Screw-Collier's-3.jpg|"He did stand there!—But high up, beyond the lawn and at the very top of the tower" File:The-Turn-of-the-Screw-Collier's-4.jpg|"Holding my candle high, till I came within sight of the tall window" File:The-Turn-of-the-Screw-Collier's-6.jpg|"He presently produced something that made me drop straight down on the stone slab" File:The-Turn-of-the-Screw-Collier's-7.jpg|"I must have thrown myself, on my face, on the ground" In October 1898 the novella appeared with the short story "Covering End" in a volume titled ''The Two Magics'', published by Macmillan in New York City and by Heinemann in London.{{cite book |last=James |first=Henry |date=1996 |title=Complete Stories, 1892–1898|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VYMqNHbJwK8C&pg=PA941 |location=New York |publisher=[[Library of America]] |page=941 |isbn=978-1-883011-09-3}} James revised ''The Turn of the Screw'' ten years later for his ''[[New York Edition]]''.{{sfn|Orr|2009|p=24}} In ''The Collier's Weekly Version of The Turn of the Screw'' (2010), the tale is presented in its original serial form with a detailed analysis of the changes James made over the years. Among many other revisions, James changed the children's ages.{{cite book|url=http://coffeetownpress.com/henry-jamess-the-turn-of-the-screw/ |title=The Collier's Weekly Version of The Turn of the Screw|author=Henry James|editor=Beidler, Peter G.|publisher=Coffeehouse Press}} == Adaptations == ===Film, stage, and television=== {{multiple image | footer = Among the various adaptations and reworkings of James's novella are ''[[The Turn of the Screw (opera)|The Turn of the Screw]]'', a 1954 opera by [[Benjamin Britten]] ''(left, 1968)'' and ''[[The Nightcomers]]'', a 1972 prequel film directed by [[Michael Winner]] ''(right, photographed 2010)'' and starring [[Marlon Brando]]. | align = right | image1 = Benjamin Britten, London Records 1968 publicity photo for Wikipedia.jpg | width1 = {{#expr: (200 * 725 / 878) round 0}} | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Michael Winner, 2010 (cropped).jpg | width2 = {{#expr: (200 * 695 / 963) round 0}} | alt2 = | caption2 = }} ''The Turn of the Screw'' has been the subject of numerous adaptations and reworkings in a variety of media, and these reworkings and adaptations have, themselves, been analysed in the academic literature on Henry James and [[neo-Victorian]] culture.{{Cite journal|title= The mad child in the attic: John Harding's ''Florence & Giles'' as a neo-victorian reworking of ''The Turn of the Screw''|journal= Neo-Victorian Studies|year=2012|author=Dinter, Sandra|volume=5|issue=1|pages= 60–88}} It was adapted to [[The Turn of the Screw (opera)|an opera]] by [[Benjamin Britten]], which premiered in 1954, and the opera has been filmed on numerous occasions.{{sfn|Haralson|Johnson|2009|p=293}} The novella was adapted as a ballet score (1980) by [[Luigi Zaninelli]],{{cite journal|title= Film Music as Sister Art: Adaptations of 'The Turn of the Screw.'|journal=Mosaic (Winnipeg)|author=Brown, Monika|year= 1998|volume=31|issue=1}} and separately as a ballet (1999) by Will Tucket for the [[Royal Ballet]].Jays, David (July 1, 2006). "[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/cc6430ac-089e-11db-b9b2-0000779e2340.html Ballet – From page to stage]". ''[[Financial Times]]''. Retrieved January 5, 2015. [[Harold Pinter]] directed ''[[The Innocents (play)|The Innocents]]'' (1950), a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] play which was an adaptation of ''The Turn of the Screw'',{{Cite book|page= 32|title=Harold Pinter|author= Baker, William|year=2008|publisher= A&C Black|isbn= 978-0-8264-9970-7}} and a subsequent eponymous stage play, adapted by [[Rebecca Lenkiewicz]] was presented in a co-production with [[Hammer Film Productions|Hammer]] at the [[Almeida Theatre]], London, in January 2013.{{cite news|last=Masters|first=Tim|title=Hammer takes first steps on stage in Turn of the Screw|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-20462277|accessdate=13 February 2013|publisher=BBC News|date=23 November 2012}} There have been numerous film adaptations of the novel. The critically acclaimed ''[[The Innocents (1961 film)|The Innocents]]'' (1961), directed by [[Jack Clayton]], and [[Michael Winner]]'s prequel ''[[The Nightcomers]]'' (1972) are two particularly notable examples. Other feature film adaptations include [[Rusty Lemorande]]'s 1992 eponymous adaptation (set in the 1960s){{sfn|Haralson|Johnson|2009|p=293}}; [[Eloy de la Iglesia]]'s Spanish-language ''Otra vuelta de tuerca'' (''The Turn of the Screw'', 1985); ''[[Presence of Mind]]'' (1999), directed by Atoni Aloy; ''[[In a Dark Place]]'' (2006), directed by Donato Rotunno{{sfn|Haralson|Johnson|2009|p=293}} and [[Walter Lima Jr.]]'s Brazilian-Portuguese-language ''Através da Sombra'' (''Through the Shadow'', 2016).{{fact|date=November 2016}} ''[[The Others (2001 film)|The Others]]'' (2001) is not an adaptation but has some themes in common with James's novella.{{sfn|Haralson|Johnson|2009|p=293}}{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/may/30/classics-corner-turn-of-the-screw | work=The Guardian | first=William | last=Skidelsky | title=Classics corner: The Turn of the Screw | date=30 May 2010}} In 2018, director [[Floria Sigismondi]] filmed an adaptation of the novella, called ''[[The Turning (2019 film)|The Turning]]'', on the [[Kilruddery Estate]] in Ireland.{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.ie/entertainment/movies/movie-news/steven-spielberg-chooses-ireland-as-backdrop-to-new-horror-film-36626978.html | work=The Irish Independent | first=Melanie | last= Finn | title=Steven Spielberg chooses Ireland as backdrop to new horror film | date=21 February 2018}} Television films have included a 1959 American adaptation as part of ''[[Startime (TV series)|Ford Startime]]'' directed by [[John Frankenheimer]] and starring [[Ingrid Bergman]];{{sfn|Haralson|Johnson|2009|p=293}}{{cite book|author=Koch, J. Sarah|chapter=A Henry James Filmography|pages=335–358|editor=Griffin, Susan M.|title=Henry James Goes to the Movies|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|year=2002|isbn=978-0-8131-3324-9}} the West German ''Die sündigen Engel'' (''The Sinful Angel'', 1962),{{sfn|Hischak|2012|p=253}} a [[The Turn of the Screw (1974 film)|1974 adaptation]] directed by [[Dan Curtis]], adapted by [[William F. Nolan]];{{sfn|Haralson|Johnson|2009|p=293}} a French adaptation entitled ''Le Tour d'écrou'' (''The Turn of the Screw'', 1974); a Mexican miniseries entitled ''Otra vuelta de tuerca'' (''The Turn of the Screw'', 1981);{{sfn|Hischak|2012|p=253}} a 1982 adaptation directed by [[Petr Weigl]] primarily starring Czech actors [[lip-synching]];{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1353/not.2006.0020| title = Turn of the Screw (review)| journal = Notes| volume = 62| issue = 3| pages = 784| year = 2006| last1 = Holland | first1 = J. }} a 1990 adaptation directed by [[Graeme Clifford]]; ''The Haunting of Helen Walker'' (1995), directed by [[Tom McLoughlin]]; a 1999 adaptation directed by Ben Bolt;{{sfn|Haralson|Johnson|2009|p=293}} a low-budget 2003 version written and directed by Nick Millard;{{sfn|Hischak|2012|p=253}} the Italian-language ''Il mistero del lago'' (''The Mystery of the Lake'', 2009); and a [[The Turn of the Screw (2009 film)|2009 BBC film]] adapted by [[Sandy Welch]], starring [[Michelle Dockery]] and [[Sue Johnston]].{{sfn|Hischak|2012|p=253}} ===Literary reworkings=== Literary reworkings of ''The Turn of the Screw'' identified by James scholar Adeline R. Tintner include ''[[The Secret Garden]]'' (1911), by [[Frances Hodgson Burnett]]; "Poor Girl" (1951), by [[Elizabeth Taylor (novelist)|Elizabeth Taylor]]; ''The Peacock Spring'' (1975), by [[Rumer Godden]]; ''[[Ghost Story (Straub novel)|Ghost Story]]'' (1975) by [[Peter Straub]]; "The Accursed Inhabitants of House Bly" (1994) by [[Joyce Carol Oates]]; and ''Miles and Flora'' (1997)—a sequel—by [[Hilary Bailey]].{{sfn|Tintner|1998|pages=371–82}} Further literary adaptations identified by other authors include ''[[Affinity (novel)|Affinity]]'' (1999), by [[Sarah Waters]]; ''A Jealous Ghost'' (2005), by [[A. N. Wilson]];{{sfn|Heilmann|2010|pages=111–30}} and ''Florence & Giles'' (2010), by [[John Harding (author)|John Harding]]. Young adult novels inspired by ''The Turn of the Screw'' include ''The Turning'' (2012) by [[Francine Prose]]{{cite magazine|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/francine-prose/turning/|title=''The Turning'' by Francine Prose|magazine=[[Kirkus (magazine)|Kirkus]]|date=1 August 2012|accessdate=10 September 2016}} and ''Tighter'' (2011) by [[Adele Griffin]].{{cite magazine|url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/adele-griffin/tighter/|title= ''Tighter'' by Adele Griffin|magazine=[[Kirkus (magazine)|Kirkus]]|date=15 April 2011|accessdate=10 September 2016}} ==In popular culture== ''The Turn of the Screw'' has also influenced television.{{cite journal|title= To think and watch ''the'' Evil: ''The Turn of the Screw'' as cultural reference in television from ''Dark Shadows'' to ''C.S.I.''|author= Sborgi, Anna Viola|journal=Babel: Littératures plurielles|year=2011|volume= 24|pages= 181–94 (see paragraph 8)|url= http://babel.revues.org/184}} In December 1968, the ABC daytime drama ''[[Dark Shadows]]'' featured a storyline based on ''The Turn of the Screw''. In the story, the ghosts of [[Quentin Collins]] and Beth Chavez haunted the west wing of Collinwood, possessing the two children living in the mansion. The story led to a year-long story in the year 1897, as Barnabas Collins travelled back in time to prevent Quentin's death and stop the possession. In early episodes of ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'' ("[[Cathexis (Star Trek: Voyager)|Cathexis]]", "[[Learning Curve (Voyager episode)|Learning Curve]]" and "[[Persistence of Vision (Voyager episode)|Persistence of Vision]]"), [[Captain Kathryn Janeway]] is seen on the [[holodeck]] acting out scenes from a holonovel which appears to be based on ''The Turn of the Screw''.{{cite book|author=Ruditis, Paul|year=2003|title=Star Trek Voyager Companion|location=New York|publisher= Simon and Schuster|p=25|isbn= 978-0-743-41751-8}} == Editions == [[File:The-Turn-of-the-Screw-LaFarge.jpg|right|thumb|upright=1|1898 illustration by [[John La Farge]] featured in the original ''Collier's Weekly'' serialization]] '''Pre-millennium''' * ''The Turn of the Screw: Authoritative Text, Contexts, Criticism'', edited by Robert Kimbrough (New York: W.W. Norton & Company, 1966) [no ISBN]. * ''The Tales of Henry James'', edited by [[Edward Wagenknecht]] (New York: Frederick Ungar Publishing Co. 1984) {{ISBN|0-8044-2957-X}}. * ''The Aspern Papers'' and ''The Turn of the Screw'', with an introduction and notes by Anthony Curtis (Harmondsworth: Penguin, 1986) {{ISBN|9780141439907}}. {{small|(Includes excerpts from the New York Preface to both novellas. Does not include a list of suggested further reading).}} * ''The Turn of the Screw: Authoritative Text, Contexts, Criticism'', edited by Deborah Esch and Jonathan Warren (New York: W.W. Norton & Company, 1999) {{ISBN|0-393-95904-X}}. {{small|(Offers a selection of criticism, including an excerpt from Edmund Wilson's study of the novella).}} '''Post-millennium''' *''The Turn of the Screw and Other Stories'', edited by T.J. Lustig (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2008) {{ISBN|978-0-199-53617-7}}. * ''The Collier's Weekly Version of The Turn of the Screw'', edited by Peter G. Beidler ([[Seattle]]: Coffeetown Press, 2010) {{ISBN|978-1-60381-018-0}}. * ''The Turn of the Screw and Other Stories'', edited by Kimberly Reed ([[Peterborough, Ontario|Peterborough]]: Broadview Press, 2010) {{ISBN|978-1-770-48255-5}}. * ''The Turn of the Screw'', edited by [[David Bromwich]] (New York: Penguin Classics, 2011) {{ISBN|978-0-141-44135-1}}. == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==Works cited== *{{cite book|title=Critical Companion to Henry James: A Literary Reference to His Life and Work|last1=Haralson|first1= Eric L. |last2=Johnson|first2=Kendall |year= 2009|publisher= Infobase Publishing|isbn= 978-1-4381-1727-0|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Heilmann|first=Ann|year=2010|chapter=The Haunting of Henry James: Jealous Ghosts, Affinities and ''The Others''|editor1=Arias, Rosario|editor2= Pulham, Patricia|title=Haunting and Spectrality in Neo-Victorian Fiction: Possessing the Past|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn= 978-0-230-24674-4|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|title=American Literature on Stage and Screen: 525 Works and Their Adaptations |last= Hischak|first=Thomas S.|publisher= McFarland|year=2012|ISBN=978-0-7864-9279-4|ref=harv}} *{{cite book |last=Orr |first=Leonard |year=2009 |title=James' The Turn of the Screw: A Readers Guide |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4hfmtG5wqlYC&pg=PA24 |location=London, New York |publisher=Bloomsbury |ref=harv |isbn=978-0-8264-3019-9}} *{{cite book|last=Simon|first=Linda|title=The Critical Reception of Henry James: Creating a Master|year=2007|publisher=Camden House|location=London|ref=harv|isbn=978-1-571-13319-9}} *{{cite book|last=Slide|first=Anthony|year=2013|title=Fifty Classic British Films, 1932-1982: A Pictorial Record|publisher=Courier Corporation|ref=harv|isbn=978-0-486-14851-9}} *{{cite book|last=Tintner|first=Adeline R.|year=1998|title=Henry James's Legacy: The Afterlife of His Figure and Fiction |publisher= Louisiana State University Press|ref=harv|isbn= 978-0-807-12157-3}} ==Further reading== *Smith, Allan Lloyd. "A Word Kept Back in "The Turn of the Screw". In Clive Bloom (ed), ''Creepers: British Horror and Fantasy in the Twentieth Century.'' London and Boulder CO: Pluto Press, 1993, pp. 47–63. == External links == {{Commons category|The Turn of the Screw}} {{Wikisource|The Turn of the Screw}} '''Primary sources''' *[http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/209 ''The Turn of the Screw''] at [[Project Gutenberg]] (1898 book version) *[https://americanliterature.com/author/henry-james/book/the-turn-of-the-screw/summary ''The Turn of the Screw''] via ''[[American Literature (journal)|American Literature]]'' (full text) * {{librivox book | title=The Turn of the Screw | author=Henry JAMES}} *[http://www.henryjames.org.uk/prefaces/text12.htm Author's preface to the ''New York Edition'' text of ''The Turn of the Screw'' (1908)] '''Secondary discussion''' *[http://www.loa.org/volume.jsp?RequestID=63§ion=notes Note on the various texts of ''The Turn of the Screw''] at the [[Library of America]] web site. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100212104012/http://englishtouringopera.org.uk/about-eto/opera-synopses/britten-the-turn-of-the-screw/ Synopsis of ''The Turn of the Screw''] from the [[English Touring Opera]] *[http://www.turnofthescrew.com/ turnofthescrew.com] A History of Its Critical Interpretations 1898–1979 Edward J. Parkinson, PhD {{Henry James}} {{The Turn of the Screw}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Turn Of The Screw, The}} [[Category:1898 American novels]] [[Category:1898 British novels]] [[Category:Frame stories]] [[Category:British novellas]] [[Category:American horror novels]] [[Category:American gothic novels]] [[Category:Ghost novels]] [[Category:Novels adapted into television programs]] [[Category:American novellas]] [[Category:American novels adapted into films]] [[Category:Fiction with unreliable narrators]] [[Category:1898 fantasy novels]] [[Category:Novels set in Essex]] [[Category:American novels adapted into plays]] [[Category:Works originally published in Collier's]] [[Category:Novels by Henry James]] [[Category:British novels adapted into films]]

revision.text:
[[File:Theo van Hoytema.jpg|thumb|185px|Theo van Hoytema
(date unknown)]] '''Theodorus van Hoytema''', or '''Hoijtema''' (18 December 1863, [[The Hague]] - 28 August 1917, The Hague) was a Dutch [[lithographer]], illustrator and graphic designer, known for his book covers and calendars; especially those depicting birds. == Biography == [[File:Het leelijke jonge eendje.jpg|thumb|left|175px|Illustration from
''The Ugly Duckling'']] His father was Secretary-General of the Department of Finance.[http://resources.huygens.knaw.nl/bwn1880-2000/lemmata/bwn3/hoijtema Brief biography] @ Huygens/Resources. He was the youngest of eight children. Both of his parents died during the 1870s, so he and some siblings moved to Klein Stadwijk, a village in [[Voorschoten]]. There, he received his first drawing lessons from his eldest sister. He attended the [[Stedelijk Gymnasium Leiden]] and, together with two of his older brothers, passed an exam that enabled them to find work at a financial firm. Theo, however, was not satisfied with office life and decided to become an artist.[http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/LotDetailsPrintable.aspx?intObjectID=4180371 Brief biography] @ Christie's. He began by taking drawing classes at the [[Royal Academy of Art, The Hague|Royal Academy of Art]]. While there, he drew and painted the stuffed animals at the [[Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historie]] in Leiden. As a result, his uncle Adriaan van Oordt, Director of [[Brill Publishers]], was able to get him his first commissions doing scientific illustrations. From 1889 to 1890, he became interested in lithography. That same year, he took up temporary residence in a garden house at {{ill|Binckhorst Castle|nl|Kasteel de Binckhorst}}. The following year, after the success of his first picture book about birds (''Hoe de vogels aan een koning kwamen''), he was married and moved to [[Loosduinen]]. The marriage was, however, short-lived and childless, ending in divorce in 1902. In 1892, he became a member of the [[Haagsche Kunstkring]] and joined [[Arti et Amicitiae]] in 1893. That same year, he produced an illustrated edition of ''[[The Ugly Duckling]]'' by [[Hans Christian Andersen]], followed by several more bird-themed picture books. He continued to move, restlessly, first to [[Voorburg]] then, in 1897, to [[Hilversum]]. For a time, he stayed with family members in London. His health became fragile and he was hospitalized for much of 1904 and 1905. He also spent a short time at a psychiatric sanatorium. When released, he went to live with a sister in The Hague and remained there, under her care, for the rest of his life. Despite his illness, it was during this period that he created the calendars that made him famous. His designs also formed the basis for pottery and furniture. He and his wife were the models for the main characters in ''Leo en Gerda'' (1911), a novel by {{ill|Aegidius Willem Timmerman|nl}} about the generation of artists who began their careers in the 1880s.[http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/timm004tims01_01/timm004tims01_01_0016.php Items on Timmerman] @ [[Digital Library for Dutch Literature|DBNL]]. A street was named after him in 1923, and a monument was placed there in 2009. ==Selected works== File:Hoytema-Peacock.jpg|Peacock
(calendar illustration) File:Hoytema-Swans.jpg|Swans in the River File:WLANL - kwispeltail - Return of the stork.jpg|Return of the Stork File:Hoytema-Dead.jpg|Dead Bird under the Branches ==References== {{reflist}} == Further reading == *"Herinneringen aan Theo van Hoytema", an article by J.G. Veldheer in the monthly journal ''Onze Kunst'', September 1918. *I.M. de Groot, ''De grafiek van Theo van Hoytema'' (exhibition catalog), [[Rijksmuseum]], 1977 * Marjan Boot, et al., ''Theo van Hoytema 1863-1917'', Waanders, 1999, in conjunction with the [[Gemeentemuseum Den Haag]] and the [[Drents Museum]]. {{ISBN|90-400-9387-3}} == External links == {{commons category|Theo van Hoytema}} *[http://hoytemacalendars.blogspot.com/2010/01/man-for-all-seasons-1902.html The Hoytema Calendars] @ BlogSpot. * [http://www.kb.nl/themas/kinderboeken-en-strips/klassieke-kinderboeken/hoe-de-vogels-aan-een-koning-kwamen ''Hoe de vogels aan een koning kwamen''] (How the Birds Came to a King) @ the [[National Library of the Netherlands]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hoytema, Theo van}} [[Category:1863 births]] [[Category:1917 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch graphic designers]] [[Category:Dutch illustrators]] [[Category:Dutch lithographers]] [[Category:Birds in art]] [[Category:Artists from The Hague]] [[Category:Calendars]]

revision.text:
The term '''twitter bomb''' or '''tweet bomb''' (also spelled as one word) refers to posting numerous (pejoratively, "[[spamming]]") [[Twitter|Tweets]] with the same [[hashtag]]s and other similar content, including @messages, from multiple accounts, with the goal of [[advertising]] a certain [[Internet meme|meme]], usually by filling people's Tweet feeds with the same message, and making it a "[[Twitter#Trending topics|trending topic]]" on Twitter.{{cite book|author=Mary C. Joyce|title=Digital Activism Decoded: The New Mechanics of Change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w3AOzoq7VfIC&pg=PA221|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=30 April 2010|publisher=IDEA|isbn=978-1-932716-60-3|page=221}}[[Ethan Zuckerman]], [http://www.ethanzuckerman.com/blog/2012/04/20/the-tweetbomb-and-the-ethics-of-attention "The Tweetbomb and the Ethics of Attention"], April 20, 2012, Last accessed on April 30, 2012.J. Ratkiewicz, M. D. Conover, M. Meiss, B. Gonçalves, A. Flammini, [[Filippo Menczer|F. Menczer]], [http://truthy.indiana.edu/site_media/pdfs/ratkiewicz_icwsm2011_truthy.pdf "Detecting and Tracking Political Abuse in Social Media"], ''Proc. 5th International AAAI Conference on Weblogs and Social Media'' ICWSM (2011). This may be done by individual users, fake accounts, or both.{{cite web|author = |url = http://www.newser.com/story/124685/obama-loses-37k-followers-in-twitter-bombs.html|title = 37K Followers Ditch Obama After Twitter Bomb - @BarackObama tweets handles of GOP legislators, state by state|publisher = [[Newser]]|date = |accessdate = 2012-04-30}} == Advertising == Twitter bombing may be used for commercial advertising. An early example from {{Nowrap|April 2009}} referred to advertising a [[YouTube]] video series [[Ask a Ninja]]. == Politics == Twitter bombing is one of [[repertoire of contention|the tools]] used in [[Internet activism]], both by mainstream politicians like [[Barack Obama]] and by groups like [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]].{{cite book|author1=John Clifford Green|author2=Daniel J. Coffey|title=The State of the Parties: The Changing Role of Contemporary American Parties|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lx6VsVR0g-4C&pg=PA178|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=1 September 2010|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7425-9954-3|page=178}}{{cite web|author=Chris Richardson |url=http://www.webpronews.com/anonymous-plans-24-hour-tweet-bomb-to-fight-cispa-2012-04 |title=Anonymous Plans "24 Hour Tweet Bomb" To Fight CISPA |publisher=WebProNews |date=2012-04-20 |accessdate=2012-04-30}} The earliest recorded usage of the Twitter bomb is from August 2008, when it was used by bloggers Liza Sabater and Kenneth Quinnell in response to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] use of the #dontgo [[hashtag]] relating to [[Offshore drilling|offshore oil drilling]].Kenneth Quinnell, [http://floridaspeaks.blogspot.com/2008/08/twitter-bomb.html "Twitter Bomb"], Florida Speaks blog, August 5, 2008, Last accessed on August 27, 2012. The term was used for other purposes in 2008, but the other meanings have since disappeared. An example of a Twitter bomb was the campaign organized by online activists in response to a July 31, 2009 ''[[Washington Post]]'' article on [[Hillary Clinton]] that was deemed [[sexist]].{{cite book|author=Mary C. Joyce|title=Digital Activism Decoded: The New Mechanics of Change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w3AOzoq7VfIC&pg=PA156|accessdate=30 April 2012|date=30 April 2010|publisher=IDEA|isbn=978-1-932716-60-3|pages=155–156}} In 2011, it was used extensively by Barack Obama's campaign staff to encourage his followers to contact Congress and encourage them to reach a compromise during the [[United States debt-ceiling crisis of 2011]]. Shortly thereafter, @BarackObama lost about 37,000 followers. == Positive Impacts == Twitter bombing/spamming can provide exposure to current events that are not being exposed enough from mainstream media. Dhiraj Murthy writes:
Twitter has received significant media attention in its use to disseminate information during disasters, including the 2008 Mumbai bomb blasts (Dolnick, 2008) and the January 2009 crash of US Airways flight 1549 (Beaumont, 2009).Murthy, Dhiraj. "Twitter: Microphone for the masses?." ''Media Culture and Society'' 33.5 (2011): 779.
Linking this with the use of hashtag, see hashtag activism, news and information can be spread around the internet at a rapid pace with the use of hashtags. == Comparison to online spam == The use of the Twitter bomb tactics has been known to misfire, as people might be offended by spamming, or [[Troll (Internet)|trolling]].{{cite web |url=http://www.partisans.org/2012/04/social-activism |title=Social Media Activism and the (In)justice of the Mob |publisher=Partisans |date=2012-04-26 |accessdate=2012-04-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120506002256/http://www.partisans.org/2012/04/social-activism |archivedate=2012-05-06 |df= }} Spammers have several goals, which are phishing, advertising, or malware distribution. Unlike traditional online spamming, such as email, Twitter has a limit of only 140 characters per tweet. Therefore, a Twitter bomb often include URLs in their tweets in order to send others users to their malicious pages online.Song, Jonghyuk, Sangho Lee, and Jong Kim."Spam filtering in twitter using sender-receiver relationship." ''Recent Advances in Intrusion Detection''. Springer Berlin Heidelberg, 2011. Unlike email spam, Twitter bombs may require participation from their targeted users. Fake accounts are a common source of Twitter bombs. In order to avoid Twitter's spam filters and to overcome their lack of followers, Twitter bombs are often sent as a reply to existing tweets about the same topic. This is done in hopes that the authors of the existing tweets will retweet the response to their own followers, spreading the Twitter bomb before the fake account is deleted. With regards to numbers, an example of a Twitter bomb analyzed in one research paper described how nine fake user accounts produced 929 tweets in 138 minutes, all with a [[URL]] to a political website, presenting negative views on the U.S. politician [[Martha Coakley]].P. Metaxas, E. Mustafaraj, [http://journal.webscience.org/317/ "From Obscurity to Prominence in Minutes: Political Speech and Real-Time Search"], ''In: Proceedings of the WebSci10: Extending the Frontiers of Society On-Line, April 26-27th, 2010, Raleigh, NC: US (2010). The message might have reached about 60,000 before being eliminated by Twitter as spam.Neil Savage. 2011. [http://cacm.acm.org/magazines/2011/3/105332-twitter-as-medium-and-message/fulltext "Twitter as Medium and Message"], ''[[Communications of the ACM]]'' 54, no. 3 (March 2011), 18–20. [http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/1897852.1897860 DOI:10.1145/1897852.1897860] == Criticism == Many Twitter users find comfort in sharing their ideas and thoughts to the general public. Though Twitter can be utilized to spread awareness of a variety of issues and [http://www.kcet.org/socal/departures/youthvoices/education-notes/twitter-party-using-twitter-to-raise-awareness-teen-dating-abuse.html causes], many can take advantage and post numerous tweets that may be viewed as spam. Twitter's rule [https://support.twitter.com/articles/18311 page] considers tweets "spam" once a user displays multiple tweets with unrelated hashtags to a certain topic, or continues to post multiple tweets of the same content in one account. Some instances, these tweets can be viewed as trolling once they begin to seek out other Twitter users for arguments about controversial issues. ==See also== *[[Google bomb]] *[[Social bot]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Twitter Navigation}} [[Category:Culture jamming]] [[Category:Internet-based activism]] [[Category:Internet slang]] [[Category:Twitter]] [[Category:Words coined in the 2000s]]

revision.comment: Update cite parameters/links (''Deadline Hollywood''), overlinking, consolidate citations, and genfixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{about|the novel|the television series|Witches of East End (TV series)}} {{distinguish|The Witches of Eastwick}} {{Infobox book| <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = Witches of East End | title_orig = | translator = | image = Witches of East End Cover.jpg | caption = First edition cover | author = [[Melissa de la Cruz]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = The Beauchamp Family | genre = [[Contemporary Fantasy]] | publisher = [[Hyperion Books]] | release_date = June 21, 2011 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover|Hardback]] & [[e-book]]) | pages = 288 pp (first edition, hardback) | isbn = 1401323901 | dewey= | congress= | oclc= | preceded_by = | followed_by = Serpent's Kiss }}
'''''Witches of East End''''' is a 2011 [[novel]] by author [[Melissa de la Cruz]] and the first entry in her ''Beauchamp Family'' series. It was published on June 21, 2011, by [[Hyperion Books]] and follows a family of Long Island witches struggling against dark forces conspiring against them. ''Witches of East End'' is de la Cruz's first adult novel; she said she wrote it with her [[Blue Bloods (novel series)|Blue Bloods]] audience in mind because "many of them will soon be adults" and the book takes place in the same universe as the ''Blue Bloods'' series.<ref>{{cite web|last=Yin|first=MaryAnne|title=Melissa de la Cruz on Writing for Adults|url=http://www.mediabistro.com/galleycat/melissa-de-la-cruz-on-writing-for-adults_b31227|publisher=GalleyCat|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> The novel currently has two sequels: ''Serpent's Kiss'' (2012) and ''Winds of Salem'' (2013).
A television series adaptation, ''[[Witches of East End (TV series)|Witches of East End]]'', debuted October 6, 2013, on [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]].<ref name="premieredate">{{cite web|title=TCA: Lifetime's 'Witches Of East End' Debuts Oct. 6|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/tca-lifetimes-witches-of-east-end-debuts-oct-6/|website=Deadline Hollywood|accessdate=July 26, 2013}}</ref>
==Synopsis== Joanna Beauchamp has lived off the coast of Long Island for many centuries. She and her daughters Freya and Ingrid are immortal witches, cursed to spend the rest of their days without the use of their substantial powers due to the family's involvement in the [[Salem Witch Trials]]. Joanna has the power to heal and bring the dead back to life. Ingrid can tell the future and weave magical [[knotwork]], while Freya can craft potions and charms. They've spent years hiding their true nature from others, something that provides no small amount of frustration due to how much they want to help others. It's only after Freya becomes engaged to the mysterious Bran (Branford) Gardiner (this character was renamed Dash in the TV series), and somehow becomes unwillingly infatuated with his brother Killian, that the Beauchamps seem to start breaking their curse, and slowly begin to cast magic once again. However one small spell turns into several as the Beauchamps begin to fall into the routine of using magic. It's through this everyday usage that they discover that a mysterious presence is at work within the town, making the women barren, unleashing a strange silvery substance into the waters, and ruining the local wildlife.
As Bran is continually away on trips to promote a charitable organisation that his family runs, Freya is often left alone with Killian. This closeness eventually culminates in her once again sleeping with Killian after he assists her with a busy weekend at the pub she works at. While Freya deals with the guilt from her affair and the feelings that her affair with Killian brings up, Ingrid is conflicted by her own romantic feelings towards local police officer Matt Noble. Despite exhibiting an interest in her, Matt has begun dating a coworker, which irritates Ingrid greatly. The townspeople's ailments and the mysterious silver substance in the water eventually prompts Johanna to seek her estranged husband Norman (this character was renamed Viktor in the TV series) in New York, leaving her daughters alone to deal with a growing unrest in the town as a whole. The family is eventually charged with various crimes involving an attack on a local couple as well as the disappearance of a young woman that was interning at the mayor's office.
The Beauchamps eventually discover that the chaos stems from an old rivalry between [[Loki]] and [[Balder]] over Freya. It's also revealed that the entire family are gods from [[Norse mythology]] and that the silvery substance comes from the breaking down of the rifts between worlds. Freya initially believes that Killian is Loki, here to disrupt her relationship with Bran, only to discover that Bran is actually Loki and that his trips were not for charitable purposes but to encourage the destruction of the gates between the worlds. Freya and Ingrid travel into the rift to stop Loki, managing to barely succeed and return home. Once home, they are told that the Council has noticed their magic and that if they can avoid getting convicted of the crimes against them, they will be free to practice magic once more. The Beauchamps are cleared of all charges, the intern's disappearance and death being a result of the mayor's obsession with her and the attack on a local couple being the actions of Bran. Freya and Ingrid have both begun relationships with their partners, with the book ending as Freya's brother approaching her for assistance in capturing Balder/Killian, who he claims tricked him into being imprisoned for the destruction of the [[Bifröst]], which was done by Balder.
==Reception== Critical reception to ''Witches of East End'' has been mostly positive,<ref>{{cite news|last=Meadows|first=Suzannah|title=Newly Released Books|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/16/books/new-novels-by-david-ignatius-melissa-de-la-cruz-and-others.html?_r=0|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=1 November 2012|date=15 June 2011}}</ref> with ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' giving the book a rating of B+.<ref>{{cite news|title=Witches of East End (2011)|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20502644,00.html|publisher=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=1 November 2012|date=16 June 2011}}</ref> The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' commented that the book was not perfect, but that it still managed to "cast a spell".<ref>{{cite news|last=Carpenter|first=Susan|title=Book review: 'Witches of East End'|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jul/03/entertainment/la-ca-melissa-de-la-cruz-20110703|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=1 November 2012|date=3 July 2011}}</ref> Criticisms for the novel included a "clumsily executed resolution" and too much "arcane gobbledygook",<ref>{{cite web|last=Lim|first=Ronald|title=Bewitching and frustrating|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/articles/333004/bewitching-and-frustrating#.UJJefsXoSQM|publisher=Manila Bulletin|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=From Salem to the Hamptons on a broomstick|url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/books/from-salem-to-the-hamptons-on-a-broomstick-1.2979572|publisher=Newsday|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref> while praise for the novel centered around the mixture of mythologies "gel[ling] magnificently" and de la Cruz's depiction of the Beauchamp women.<ref>{{cite web|title=Review: Witches of East End|url=http://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/melissa-de-la-cruz/witches-east-end/|publisher=Kirkus Reviews|accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Book review: ‘Witches of East End,’ by Melissa de la Cruz|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/books/book-review-witches-of-east-end-by-melissa-de-la-cruz/2011/05/23/gIQAPEPCUI_story.html|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=1 November 2012|first=Brunonia|last=Barry|date=22 July 2011}}</ref>
==Television series== {{main|Witches of East End (TV series)}} In 2012, [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] announced their intentions to film a television pilot for ''Witches of East End'' with [[20th Century Fox]] and Pacific 2.1.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lifetime TV pilot shoots at Hay House |url=http://www.macon.com/2012/10/30/2231997/lifetime-tv-pilot-shoots-at-hay.html|publisher=Macon.com|accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> Filming for the pilot took place in [[Macon, Georgia]] and [[Wilmington, North Carolina]], with [[Julia Ormond]] starring as Joanna Beauchamp.<ref>{{cite web|title='Witches of East End' to start shooting in Wilmington|url=http://www.wwaytv3.com/2012/10/10/witches-of-east-end-to-start-shooting-wilmington|publisher=WWAY|accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> [[Rachel Boston]] and [[Jenna Dewan-Tatum]] were later announced as being attached to the pilot, playing Ingrid and Freya respectively.<ref>{{cite web|title=Two More Cast Additions to Lifetime's Witches of East End|url=http://www.dreadcentral.com/news/60621/two-more-cast-additions-lifetimes-witches-east-end|publisher=Dread Central|accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> The pilot loosely adapted the book's plot, with one change being that Freya and Ingrid are unaware of their magical powers or heritage.<ref>{{cite news|title='Buffy's' Tom Lenk Joins Lifetime's 'Witches of East End' The series had two seasons on lifetime and has been cancelled (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/buffy-tom-lenk-lifetime-witches-east-end-379332|work=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=3 November 2012|first=Lesley|last=Goldberg|date=16 October 2012}}</ref>
After two seasons, Lifetime cancelled ''Witches of East End'' on November 4, 2014, due to low ratings in the second season.<ref name="Abrams">{{cite web|title=Lifetime cancels 'Witches of East end'|url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2014/11/04/witches-east-end-canceled/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=November 4, 2014|last=Abrams|first=Natalie|accessdate=November 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title='Witches of East End' Canceled by Lifetime|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/witches-east-end-canceled-by-746365|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=November 4, 2014|last=Ng|first=Philiana|accessdate=November 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Witches of East End Cancelled by Lifetime After Two Seasons|url=http://deadline.com/2014/11/the-witches-of-east-end-cancelled-2-seasons-lifetime-1201273362/|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=November 4, 2014|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|accessdate=November 5, 2014}}</ref> The series finale aired on October 5, 2014.<ref name="Abrams"/> Fans of the show have taken to social media and began using the hashtag #RenewWitchesofEastEnd, as well as starting a petition that has gained over 230,000 signatures.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spoilertv.com/2014/11/witches-of-east-end-ultimate.html|title=Witches of East End – The Ultimate #RenewWitchesofEastEnd Guide|last=Hetherington|first=Gavin|date=November 20, 2014|publisher=SpoilerTV.com|accessdate=November 21, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enstarz.com/articles/100389/20150801/witches-of-east-end-season-3-news-petition-gains-a-good-haul-of-more-signatures-but-is-it-too-late-for-a-renewal-video.htm|title='Witches Of East End' Season 3 News: Petition Gains A Good Haul Of More Signatures, But Is It Too Late For A Renewal?|last=Machado|first=Sam|publisher=Enstarz.com|date=August 1, 2015|accessdate=August 1, 2015}}</ref>
